content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												This game could not have been any more of a pleasure. I must admit that when I decided to purchase the game, there was a little bit of worry coming alongside my purchase, but once I began playing, all my worries were gone. Abyss Odyssey is a game perfect for anyone seeking a challenge. After playing the game for a while I began to try to dig into the combat system to just be impressed over and over again with how interesting it is.The combat in this game has a similar feel to it as Smash Bros. Abyss Odyssey is not as loose at Smash, but the way you move and attack are similar. As you progress down deeper and fight you will level up your character and find alternate attacks you can equip to expand on your potential. Depending on what kind of skills you equip, you'll expand your combo potential and/or give yourself benifits such as more ranged attacks.I feel the need to stress that if you're not interested in games that will push you and challenge you, this game is not for you. If you want a game that will reward you with feeling like you really accomplished something worthwhile, then you need this game in your library.I don't like to rate games on a number scale because I don't believe that can be accurate, so I would rather inform you on what the game has to offer instead of trying to sell you on buying it regardless of your type of game. The player type I would recommend this game to is one who desires a difficult game with high reward in term of accomplishment. A player who is more into disecting a game to play it at its fullest potential will enjoy this game. A player who is interested in jumping in and just fighting without interest in mastery of the game will not get as much out of the game.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014



YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: Abyss Odyssey 

			Views: 195		

			Abyss Odyssey is a platformer brawler, available on Steam here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/255070/ Join us at Twitter or Facebook if that is your thing: https://twitter.com/TheSocioPsycho...		

     Abyss Odyssey is a platform brawler with roguelite elements.  The story and platforming are simplistic but effective, and the voice acting is professionally done, but the game suffers from many small annoyances that chip away from immersion, and hurt it.     The game is artistically beautiful, full of rich detail and color, and is very distinctive.  The levels are randomly generated, which is a strong point of the game, as it offers a refreshing take at a basic linear path.   The characters and creatures are unique and creative, which draws you into the environment.     Unfortunately, the inventory is extremely limited, and the UI adds extra unnecessary steps making upgrading of items clunky and time consuming. The allies that help you in battle, should they kill the enemy, you will not gain any experience even if you take the enemy down from 100% hp to 5% and your ally gets final hit.  More than all of this, though, the combat is the downfall of this game; it is sluggish and clunky,with slow response times from the buttons and basic combat abilities, and a delay between those abilities, taking away from the fluidity of the game.     The enemies and characters are varied in their abilities, but the hero has a limited amount of attack, limiting the variability of combat.       While the voice acting and story progression of this game is well done, and the artwork and music are beautiful, the clunky inventory and clumsy UI combined with the sluggish combat makes for an awkward experience that I cannot recommend.For more reviews check out the channel here http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												This game has beautiful visuals, great acting, and a great premise. Unfortunately it's difficult in ways that make it seem lazy, rather than by design; its controls are not quite so tight as they need to be, and while it does have the excitement of random dungeon layouts every time, it unfortunately is so random that it's frequently unfair. It would have been far better if it took the player's level and gave it any thought, but that is beyond Abyss Odyssey. While you do retain your money and experience even after a defeat, you unfortunately don't retain any items, adding to the frustration. The promise of playing as any number of characters is also similarly not what it is presented to be; an extremely unwieldy and difficult-to-use soul capture system, through the woefully slow-filling mana, is used to temporarily command that soul. All things considered, it's not really that worth bothering with. Additionally, the character designs for female characters in the game are elegant and beautiful, but of course male characters are either placeholders or hideous. Maybe if you like teeth-grindingly annoying 'roguelikes', you'll like this. But I personally found the promise far greater than the actual game itself. It's a shame, because I really liked the art nouveau aesthetic and the concept of the game. It simply did not deliver with all it seemed to offer.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Abyss Odyssey is a rather different game than I am used to seeing these days. The play style reminded me of the original Ninja Gaiden, but more modern. Each level is procedurally generated, which means that every time you play the game you will have a different experience. Visually I think there are certain aspects which look nice, such as the backgrounds, but the characters don't seem to have a lot of detail and are very repetitive. There isn't a lot of variety in the way the characters look. I do like the different levels, but after a while it feels like you are playing the same ones over and over even though they look different. I think a more robust fighting system and some NPC variety would go a long way toward making this a better game, but it can still be fun to play.

												The combat in this seems frustrating because it's not a side scrolling roguelike. It's a side scrolling roguelike fighting game. Remember that this is Atlus and ACE. This is what they do. The reviews here driving the response down to Mixed almost made me not play it. I am thankful I decided to trust my own judgement. Because as others have said when you start using your parries, blocking and dodging correctly you can snowball pretty quickly (and be humbled just as fast).The backgrounds and overall theme fascinate me to no end. I love the art style and general surreal nature of the story. Which is essentially that a Warlock so powerful he can shift reality is  locked into a dream and is for all intents and purposes the equivalent of the roguelike Random Number God. Which seems crazy enough, but this particular warlock is also apparently braindamaged and mentally traumatized. Leading to some truly Silent Hill level business.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												Abyss Odyssey offers what feels like a cross between a Souls-like and Street Fighter-like approach to complex combat mechanics amidst a gorgeous, sometimes whimsical, eerie 2D background.  Yes, the controls can feel counter-intuitive and frustrating as others have mentioned, but once you get into the groove of dashing, parrying, and cancelling out of and into actions and abilities, fighting begins to feel extremely rewarding.  You will most definitely want to use a controller.Enemy AI is sophisticated enough to make battle feel like a UFC squaredance.  Foes read you, and they are quite good at it.  They anticipate moves and react accordingly.  Hitboxes are fair and accurate. Enemies often provide enough time and space between moments of engagement to allow you some room for planning attacks.  Add to this the fact that each character has unique moves and skill sets, and the main playable characters have ability unlocks and customizable loadouts, and you have a ton of great replayability.  There are plenty of characters to master as you collect the souls of monsters you encounter, including some boss souls--gotta catch 'em all!Itemization leaves a little something to be desired.  The few weapons and items available have standard fantasy attributes (fire, ice, poison, curse, charm), and while they look aesthetically pleasing, help destroy foes more easily, and add another nice layer of complexity and fun to combat (especially charming and freezing), more could have been done by the developers to diversify and add to the repertoire.If you enjoy rewarding difficulty with precision control mastery, stunning art and music, smooth pacing from stage to stage, and a fairly unique spin on 2D action platforming, get this at full price or on sale.  Either way, it's worth it.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												TL;DRFun game, but punishes you on the regular until you learn the ropes, expect to die... A LOT.Pros+Collecting Enemy Souls to transform into enemy characters.Rogue-like - random levels Hard to master combatCo-OpCons-Combat feels very clunky at firstRogue-like is not for everyoneNo save pointsInexperienced players can be a huge hinderance in Co-Op===================================================================I wasn't sure about Abyss Oddyssey when I first fired it up. It felt like a really clunky side-scrolling beat 'em up, but I persevered as I'd coaxed a friend into playing Co-Op and found something well worth your time if you give it a chance. There are some cool features to this game, such as the fact you've technically got up to 3 lives. Whilst your main character has one life, if you die, you respawn as a variety of weaker soldiers (I believe there are 3 in total, one different soldier per main character) which you can use to reach an altar to respawn. However, you also have the ability to collect fallen enemies' souls and then by using altars, you can purchase the ability to transform into the various enemies, they have their own health bars and you can switch between the main character and the enemy at will. If there wasn't a tactical reason to use an enemy character, I'd usually use them as a buffer to keep my main character alive and developed a tiered system of use:  Enemy Character > Main Character > SoldierI had never really played a 'rogue-like' game before, so I wasn't too sure how enjoyable the random levels would be, but after quite a few deaths, you begin to realise that the randomness isn't TOO unsettling.I didn't realise this at the time, in fact, I didn't notice until the final fight with The Warlock, but this this game was created by the very same people responsible for Zeno Clash 1 & 2; two brilliant examples of First Person Beat 'Em Ups done right!Overall, I would recommend this game for around the £5 mark, I'd certainly not pay £10+ unless you are really desperate to give it a go. Fun game, good with friends, if a little frustrating for the first 3-4 hours of gameplay.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Double Dragon went Rogue.Lore: romantic magic-punk with Napoleon era soldiers wielding frost-damage muskets with bayonets against stone golems.Story: a pretty fencer girl was killed by a warlock who now dreams of her coming to kill him to stop this dreaming so she could rest in peace with her long-dead body... but the warlock's conscience makes every dream real, so she is kinda real and you just go and kill him!Game: there are like 30 randomly filled large halls on the way to the abyss bottom, some are 'easy' (kinda, if you are lucky), you make your way smashing mythical baddies in this hardcore beat'em up. Unlike many others games of the genre there are no saving checkpoints after each room and the combos are really hard to combine, blind buttonmashing doesn't help at all. You need to master movement cancelling and other advanced fighting technique. Permadeth (surprise!), start again.Graphics: swell textures, smooth animations, Unreal engine allright.Negative: close - esc, controls - a,b,x,y, trigger1... wtf? no keyboard indication in how to play.10/10 strait jacketed sharp nose pecking you to death plague doctors***************************************************************************Двойной дракон стал Бродягой.Обстановка: романтическо-магический панк с солдатами наполеоновской эры, у которых мушкеты со штыками несут замораживающий урон каменным големам.Сюжет: милая фехтовальщица была убита чародеем, который теперь видит во сне, как она идет его убивать, чтобы прекратить этот сон и упокоиться с миром в могилке… но сознание чародея делает сны реальностью, поэтому она как бы есть на самом деле, так что просто иди и убей его!Игра: порядка 30 случайно наполняемых обширных зала на пути ко дну бездны, некоторые «легкие» (типа, если повезло), пробиваемся, борясь с мифическими плохишами в этом непростом «избей их всех». В отличие от многих игр жанра отсутствуют столбики сохранения после каждой комнаты, а комбинации составлять довольно сложно, слепая долбежка по клавишам не помогает. Придется осваивать отменяемые движения и проч продвинутые техники. Смерть окончательна (сюрприз!), начинаем сначала.Графика:  гладкие текстуры, плавная анимация, Нереальный движок норм.Плохо: закрыть – esc, управление – а,б,х,у, курок1… чо за? Нет учебника по клавиатурной раскладке.10|10 чумных докторов в смирительных рубашках, заклевывающих тебя насмерть острыми клювами

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												I echo the reviews of many here who note that incredible awkwardness and unresponsiveness of the controls -- especially the unreasonable difficulty in simply getting your character to face the right direction while enemies quickly and fluidly move around you.  Animations lock you too easily and quickly.The game is obtuse and offers almost no guidance on its quirky mechanics.  And I suppose I could handle death penalty if it wasn't so random and out of your control -- sometimes you just get mobbed by 3 fluid, well-aiming enemies who simultaneously kill you very quickly while you struggle with just aiming the right direction.  I don't want to grind for gold to replace expensive weapons so I can continue when that happens.There are a lot of other minor complaints, like the common problem that it is VERY evident that the game was quickly ported over to PC from consoles with as little change as possible in UI and control scheme.  Hint: ESC should not take you to main game menu from anywhere in the game; it should function as a "back" button when you are in in-game menus.  Do NOT require the player to press the B key to exit a menu on a PC game; we hate stuff like this.  It's more irritating over time than it would first appear.  In the world of PC ergonomics, it's like putting the doorbell button to your house on the mailbox 30 feet away from the door.Again, like others, I was attracted by the art and music and visually fluid animations, but had enough of the unresponsive controls; and terrible, poorly-ported UI; and the death penalty + death by UI + need for grinding to get equipment again.Note on hours played: I played a few hours on my son's account, so you can consider me as having about 4 hours in.  If there is indeed a gem buried under the punitive barriers to entry, I couldn't bring myself to play further to see it.  If I hear that these issues have been addressed later, I would be happy to try again and revise my review.

												This is a reveiw based souly on the  my experiance with fighting games and action platformers. I saw this game  that sounded liked Smash bros. mixed with castvania. Which is actually a perfect way to describe this game's controls.Point 1 combat - The combat is slightly clunky by design. It hards to turn around because you suffer from a massive amounts of ending lag. This means if you are overwelmed getting quickly comboed  by enemies can happen.        - You can cancel all your actions into dogdes or specials you must ,however have a charge in your cancel meter(which recharges over time). This makes you have to strategize on being more offencive or defencive        - You can also block in this game but so can enemies. Both can be simply grabbed out of block.Point 2 Platfroming- The jumping in this game feels the same as Smash brother if you hit back and jump at the same time you jump back facing in the same direction as when your feet were still planted. This allows for retreating attacks in fights but can make the platforming feel a bit comberson at times. Wall jumping is also by my experiance useless. You gain so little height it is better just to try to just make the jump with your mid-air jup alone. The wall slide is also delayed so wall jumps are even more delayed and useless. You can however use dodges in the air to get extra distance which is nice.Be prepared to get used to the controls, and have fun.

content:
Posted: January 1
												The game felt really clunky and slow at first, but there's a combat mechanics guide made by one of the devs that turned the game on its head for me. It really changed how I felt about the game and it made it a whole lot more fun. I think if it was advertised as a rogue-like sidescrolling brawler, it'd have gotten more attention in its time, so as to get across the idea that it's unforgiving.The game has a combo counter but it never goes very high, but it's actually quite nice that way. Each hit feels heavier and more satisfying, that even a 5 hit combo is something to be happy about. That said, there are 10+ hit combos but it takes a bit of work. The game feels clunky at first but there's a curve that needs to be passed, it seems.It's like how people complained that Playstation All Stars (though it does have major flaws) was just a button-mashing mess when they couldn't even perform an AP Burst combo, so it became widespread that real combos weren't a thing you could really do.After getting used to the game's mechanics it's really fun, but it's a shame that the story seems to take a back seat to everything else. I love the aesthetic and the characters and wish I knew more about them. There could have been so many layers of mystery and intrigue that it feels like a lost opportunity.More enemy and level diversity would have been nice, too, even if it's enemies we couldn't transform into.Anyways, I enjoy the game a lot. I wish it got a sequel that would do it justice, but pick this game up if you have the chance- maybe wait for a sale if you have to.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												The way i would describe it by compairing games, is "rouge legacy" combined with "tobal NO.1" for ps1Problems: control / feel, Item labels / information, content / length, special moves, AI.Control / feel:game controls almost perfectly.The only problem i would face is when trying to jump and grab onto ledges, and jumping onto platforms you can pass through.The problem with ledge grabing comes from not being able to turn your character mid jump, and that the character automaticly turns when doing a wall slide.The character can only climb when facing the ledge, so many times when i would try and climb up a ledge (uses the same buttons as wallslide) i would go for a wall slide and then change direction.The problem with the platforms is that you can pass through the platform by holding jump and UP or down on the joypad. I have a habbit of holding up in games when jumping on passable ledges specificaly so I dont go through, so i had to retrain my self on that habit. There is also a problem when it comes to using a special move to go up higher than your jump I set the jump specials to UP and special, which will automaticly cause me to fall through the platforms aswell.Item labels:There is a lack of infortmation in game.The game is very basic and simple, so it is not a big fault point. That is unless you are like me, and love to have clear information on gear that your character equips. The problem is, main items have its damage values, and the magic effect / level. extra gear such as belts and rings may raise the magic effects stats by percentages, but I am not givin the base information on the main item to know excatly if what I have is doing anything significant.Content / length:The game feels short, and the main core of the game does not have alot of substance to it.Leveling only gives you the ability to add three stats to your special ablities, damage, damage reduction, add mana,a maximum of 3 times to each skill. The characters stats increase automaticly and are hidden.There are only a few special core events e.g.: buy hidden random stat till death, get a free item to be attacked later, certain walls only break to certain weapons.I beat the game in about 4 hours, and again in about 45 min to an hour and half. (I have yet to play nightmare or experiance everything)Replayablity feels limited, I expect people will get about 4 hours out of this game before moving on.I did fight a random boss after the last time I beat the game, and started another playthrough. I got my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me, but I have yet to see if it will happen again. I hate the feeling of missed oppertunity that may never return.(I returned, beat the game and the special boss a couple of more times, all playthroughs felt the same).I have mixed feelings on the AI because it does feel like they use input cheats, but at the same time I am not a programer, but I still think that is a neccessary thing for a fast pace fighting game. My feelings are the A.I feels balanced and not overly cheap.Pros:Simple combat with a basic set of moves that are easy to preform. game feels easy and natural to play.Graphics look awesome I give it a 10 for these reasons: Easy on the eyes, interesting to look at, little details, I can tell what and where things are, platforms and walkways are clear, hidden walls are not overly hidden.In game story is simple. I  skipped the starting cutscene, but still got what i think is all the story. The story is non intrusive to the gameplay.Each character is diffrent, e.g.: stats, speed, move set, specials, feel.Nothing feels tacked on.For a rougelite (intent to die alot, random level / item generation). I never felt the game was overly hard or impossible. Even the end boss fight felt “fair” in terms of fighting games.Unlockable content for free as people play. I would rather have it as I beat the game and not others.My thoughts and description:This game is a side scrolling beatum up/random generated scenarios rpg. It was alot of fun and some what challanging without being overly frustrating. There was some controls to get use to, but it didn't take long to get use to; with the exception of the cons i put above. This is a game that I recommend because there is no other game similar to it that I would recommend over it. A nich game for sure.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
Product received for free
												Abyss Odyssey is one of the best indie games I have played this year. This game is a rogue-like 2d brawler with combat similar to the Smash Bros games set in an alternate universe 1890s Chile in which the dreams of a warlock have started physically manifest in the real world and threaten everyone's wellbeing. The story is actually very interesting. However most of it is told through notes you randomly find during gameplay and a few cut scenes. Animations and combat look and feel great. Also the visuals are some of the best I've seen from a 2d platformer. They aren't on Trine or Ori levels of greatness, but they are pretty damn good. There are 3 main playable characters each with a unique weapon and moveset complex enough that this game's combat system could have easily been made for a competitive fighting game. Not only that, you are also able to captures the souls of every enemy you defeat as long as your character's level is high enough. Then you can use those enemies, all of which also have their own unique and fun movesets. For a rogue-like game, this game is actually very lenient. When you die you get the chance to continue as a soldier, which while obviously being weaker than your main character, is sufficient enough a lot of the time to last until you get to a respawn point for your character. If your soldier dies then it's truly gameover and you must restart from the beginning. When you die your character keeps all of his or her levels and gold though. As a casual player of rogue-likes I actually enjoyed this aspect because it means that every run, no matter how bad, lead to some progress. However after a while when your character gets to the higher levels and becomes somewhat rich, the game becomes a bit too easy in my opinion. Every single playthrough has a randomized map with different paths all eventually leading to the Warlock, aka the final boss. The Warlock is one of the most interesting boss designs I have seen in any video game. The idea is that as more people across the whole world beat the Warlock, all players will be contributing to the game's future content. Basically, whenever the Warlock is killed "x" number of times worldwide, the Warlock will gain a new ability for every player to experience. This is interesting because it means that people who play this game later actually get the "fuller" experience. That being said this game isn't that popular anymore so I doubt the Warlock will be changing anytime soon. Enemy AI is generally quite good. I do suspect that the AI is cheating a bit in that it probably reads some of the player's inputs directly. However, I am fine with that because the AI doesn't actually feel unfair most of the time, rather it just gives a good challenge. The game also supports local co-op and online/local pvp multiplayer (which is sadly dead)So at this point you are probably wondering. If I am giving this game so much praise (which is does indeed deserve imo), who does this game currently have a ~50% mixed steam review rating? I can pinpoint one glaring flaw with the game which didn't really bother me all too much, but will definitely bother some. Simply when you are in the middle of a combo, you cannot break out of the animation until it is done or you get hit. This makes it somewhat frustrating when you are flailing away at the wrong side, open for the enemy to attack for several seconds. This will be a deal breaker for some. For me it was not.Also other people seem to be complaining about the controls in general. Yes they don't feel extremely crisp like a triple a brawler. But on a 360 pad they felt fine for me after a little getting used to.Replayability for this game is definitely high because it's a rogue-like. However, I think due to the nature of how the player will eventually snowball because of the permanent leveling system, this game has less replayability than most rogue-likes simply because eventually it will get too easy. There is a hard mode called nightmare mode tho.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
For more reviews and gameplay videos by Morgoth, check out the profile or the Twitch channel at twitch.tv/morgoth0221I know I haven't put as much time into this game as other players, but I really plan to.  This game has a lot going for it.  The graphics have a very particular style to them and the environments are truly phenomenal.  The music is also well matched to each particular environment to really make you feel as if you were in that area.  The entire game has a very dark and eerie feel, while still portraying enough action and even slight adventure to keep the player really involved.  In short, I really like this game.I love the uniqueness of the enemies throughout the game, and the ability to capture their souls and become them is just icing on the cake because it gives real variety to a game that establishes only three main characters.  This offers an enormous amount of replayability.  I was already enjoying the game as the main character, but right when I felt like she was becoming stale, I managed to capture the soul of a burning mummy, which is freaking awesome.  At any point now, I can become that mummy whenever I want to with no penalty until he dies and his abilities are vastly different from the main character's skillset.I do have to admit a certain affinity for the ghost monk.  I mean, come on.  It's a flippin ghost monk with a two-handed longsword.  Why would this not be the character you would want to play as?  The items come in massive variety as well.  Everything from swords and halberds with different elemental attacks, down to bracelets and necklaces that offer very helpful resistances or boosts.  All too often though, I seem to come across many more weapons that just happen to be for a character I'm not playing as.  If you can never equip these weapons in the current run you're in, and the game randomly generates a new dungeon run every time, why even have weapons that aren't for you appear?  They serve no purpose, rather than to taunt you with the hope of a gleaming new item, only to find out you can't use it.  Ever.  You can't even pick them up to sell them to a merchant.I'm also not too fond of the fact that you can't keep your items from playthrough to playthrough.  The only thing that remains yours throughout is gold.  Unless there is some banking system that I'm not aware of (and please let me know if there is)  Moving on from that though.  The character skillsets are nice and varied to offer up plenty of exciting playtime without getting boring and the skillpoints that can be used to level up different skills in different ways are nice too.  However, I do wish there was even more variety with that system.And then we come to the enemies in the game.  The baddies.  And some of them, randomly, can become very, very difficult.  It's interesting that in my short time that I've played this game, I've ran into the same enemies time and time again to find that at some times, the enemies will just stand there, while other times, will be relentless in their assaults, sometimes not ever offering up opportunities for counterattacks.  And this seems to happen regardless of what difficulty the current area is at.  This can get frustrating at times, considering how slow the controls can feel at points throughout the game.  After a while though, you do get used to the controls, because at first, they are not fun to deal with.  And I think that is a side-effect of other games that have similar fighting styles such as Nintendo's Super Smash Bros. series where the controls are nearly flawless in every aspect.  The controls in Abyss Odyssey aren't that bad, Super Smash controls are just that good.  And we've been spoiled.Overall, I do really like this game and I know in the coming months I will pour countless hours into this game (because I LOVE randomly generated content like this game has to offer).  It has it's faults, but I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												It's a pretty cool fighting roguelike type of game. But it's not very good. The controls aren't great and it's the kind of game where you have a lot of trouble just trying to attack in the right direction. And there are a lot of invulnerability frames for enemies that don't make any sense. And there is very little hint as to when an enemy is taking an action. And a lot of enemies are based around a mechanic that makes some amount of damage unavoidable (which is a huge issue in a roguelike).Also, the multiplayer is *completely* unplayable for the person who joins. There is just too much lag, even with <100 ping. It looks OK, but enemies hit you before they even begin an animation and it makes blocking utterly useless. And you teleport around a lot as the physics think you meant to dash / jump when you didn't, because you are in a slightly different position on the server. And even if you had a connection good enough to have little issues with lag, there aren't any servers. If you want to play this with a friend (like I did), it's a gamble of whether or not this will even work for you.Almost a good game. Try Rogue Legacy, it's 1000x better than this one. This one just looks better, but gets very boring (even in single player).

												It's a good time killer. Get it on a sale. Basically, it's a trial and error type of game where you do runs in order to get to the final stage/boss, purchasing different weapons and upgrades along the way. content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												This is a pretty good game. It's quite hard at first, and some things are frustrating but overall it's very fun. It's like a psuedo-rogue.  The idea is that you keep replaying, but all the levels are randomly generated, so it doesn't get boring. Each time you go through you unlock something new, be it charaters, areas, or whatever. Money in this game goes quick and seems hard to ever have enough of. If you keep dying, don't worry. You keep all experience despite losing items. Personally I think the item loss after a death is one of the most frustrating parts, but the items really dont do that much for you in the end. Your level is far more important to your damage and life bar. It seems that once I gain a sufficient level I'll no longer be dying all the time. Levels 15-20 seem like they're the sweet spot for making it through the game for the first time. Keep trying and you'll make it. I use a joystick (360 for windows), and everything is perfect except for the block. Sometimes it seems sluggish, but maybe its just my timing. Anyway, I really do recommend it if you like these types of games.

												Warlocks are real.You can hop on a planeand meet the gods today.Real hardcore warlocks have to stay in caves for a few years.They seperate themselves from society.In the caves, there are entrances to the land of the dead.They commune with dead and are able to access the brains full potential.This allows warlocks to remember the future.If you happen to have had Mexican or South American relatives,you have probably heard some very unsettling stories,in order to get you to behave or go to bed.Turns out that all the stories about"La Lechuza" a flying woman with an owl body,"The Black Hand" trust me...you do not want to know,and my personal favorite the "Cukuy"were actually based on actual folklore.I could not understand how my parents storieswere scarier than horror movies! 												It's a beat'em up mixed with the 2.5 D perspective like Trine and with Rogue-like qualities of Super House of Dead Ninjas. Beat the whole game multiple times through, it's fairly easy once you've got the hang of it. The game is still being updated and includes many features like local versus mode, local co-op mode and online co-op mode. I do hope they fix the online co-op and perhaps add in an online versus mode with a leaderboard just like how there is one for how many times people have beat the game. number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												Well, I wasn't sure if I should write a review, but I saw that most of the others are just crap so I decided to ake 15 minutes and write my thoughts.This is a sort of 2D fighting game, simple and not pretencious, where you have to clear some levels until you eventually get to the big boss. Overall this is a good game, but there are some things that ought to be improved.Pros:Abyss Odyssey has a stunning visual, the artwork is marvellous, especially the artstyle of the enemies. You find yourself fighting against monsters never seen before. Also the music is beautiful, even if a bit limited. The three characters are different and balanced and the difficulty of the game is not too high. When you die you get "revived" as a second character and this is a quite god idea, so that you don't have to restart from the beginning. Cons:I'm afraid these are a bit more. There are some problems in this game that are quite annoying, The firs thing is that this game explains absolutely nothing. Ok, you know how to attack and move, but you don't know how to capture souls, how to use mana, how to respawn, and how to use the power ups. These and many other mechanics are not explained, and you need to play many times before knowing rules and tips. This might give the game more longevity but sometimes it becomes frustrating.Second is the combat. You'll find annoying trying to turn left/right, because either you attack or turn, many times I found myself swinging in the wrong direction. The counterattack is more or less useless, a bit better for the dodge, because you just have to do the same 2 combos to keep your enemies down.Other things badly managed are the inventory, when to buy weapons, and how merchants ar eplaced through the levels. Unfortunately when you die you lose your equipement (unless of course you find an altar with your soldier, but even there I lost all my potions bracelets, etc..) and you have to be lucky to find a merchant or a good weapon. Many times I was beaten because there wasn't anywhere to buy potions or a good weapon. I thought "I just need to level up and it'll change". Well that's not true because after 12 hours I still think levelling doesn't serve any purpose, the damage you inflict seems to be based on your weapon, not on your level.As for the power up section, I still don't know if it works, if I put all the power ups to the attack, mana or shield, I see the same results. One last thing I want to mention is about some traps, that in a very few cases are unavoidable and placed in a silly way. One time I died with my souls and the monk becouse I couldn't jump over a black hole (I  lost my equipement).Talking about the multiplayer, I played with a friend and the game is fun, we found it a lot easier than the single player and we enjoy beating those monsters, the only problem we have is that the game doesn't run well. Probably it's jjust us but I see my teammate halfway through the floor, and on my laptop lags. I followed instructions on some forums but still couldn't fix it. I resigned myself to lower the quality to improve the performace, and by the way I bought this laptop 2 weeks ago and it is a spaceship, this game shoul run smoothly.Well to sum up, this game is for sure enjoyable and it can keep you busy for more then 10 hours, but I wouldn't pay 15 bucks for it,  I think I got it in a bundle. There are some good ideas but some things ought to be improved, if not in this game, for the next one. Have fun playing

												Abyss Odyssey can really grow on you, if you give it a chance.The controls become intuitive with playing, whether you prefer playing with gamepad or with keyboard and mouse.Abyss Odyssey is an enjoyable experience. You can just sink somehours in it without leaving frustrated. Even if you got beaten up in an encounter, it always feels like you have a chance. It'smore of a 'Curiosity killed the cat' situation. I could justleave for the next floor, but, hey, may be there's one last treasure around the corner... Oh hell, I should've just left. Dying is a good chance to take a break. Posted: July 21, 2014
												Anyone who says this game is short doesn't understand what is going on...there are multiple locations (I've unlocked 2 others so far) and multiple characters which change slightly your approach to each level due to different combat moves and abilites. I unlocked the monk by beating the game for the first time and unlocked two other levels after trying to win using the monk (the boss is much harder as the monk for me at least).  The randomly generated levels and different weapons, moves and summons (creature tansformation thing) all reflect the hard work and effort put into this game by the Devs and is by no means incorrectly priced based purely on content. I've had a blast so far and recommend this game based upon its solid and interesting game mechanics, awesome art style, great voice cast and extensive variablilty from one level to the next.This game is only as short as you want it to be and fans of side-scolling brawlers are sure to enjoy it.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Great music, great artwork, great concept, poor execution. A clear example of a game where most of the time and money was spent on the music and artwork, but not enough time and money was spent on gameplay.- Clunky controls- Not enough feedback during fighting (sounds and visuals)- Not being able to replay previous areas - Being forced to use both the soldier and the woman. If I choose a character, that's the character I want to play. The woman is fast and agile and the soldier is slow and clunky and I just plain don't want to play the soldier character.- Annoying save point mechanic- Deceptive moving platforms where the same jump will sometimes end up with your character on the platform and most times not- Clunky Inventory and Skill Assignment UI that isn't intuitive at all- Very thin on tutorials e.g. when I see a weapon shrine and I don't know why I can't pick up the weapon in the shrine- Level design doesn't lend itself to character progression e.g. character gets new skill/ability and doesn't immediately have a space in the level to practice the skill after being given a tip on how to use the skill. Shovel Knight, Ori and Super Panda Adventures are games that do this REALLY well.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												* Combat is pretty standard hack'n'slash faire, though it feels almost like smash bros in some ways. It's a bit slow in certain cases, and you have to measure your strikes or you'll leave yourself open for enemies to murder you. The combo system is pretty deep too, and I'd comment on it further if I understood it properly.* The game expects you to die a lot, so there's no penalty for doing so, but it really just serves to prolong gameplay. The initial levels start to look a little samey, but since its all procedurally generated it's not a problem.* Visually this game is top notch. The backgrounds are gorgeous, monsters are really well done, and the dialogue portraiture is done in a really solid art-noveau style.* The music/sounds are appropriate, unobtrusive, but largely unmemorable. Probably for the best, as they aren't distracting.Here are our impressions in video form:

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Game has a Smash Bros.-esque combat system. From my extensive knowledge of smash brothers, even the best of people can get easily cheesed/comboed/killed when outnumbered with decent skill/AI; get ready to die when you're unlucky. This game requires  some skill level, and understanding of the combat system; tactiful mind knowing when to retreat, spacing, and etc. The speed of this game is not very fast paced compared to many other more recent fighting games so some might say it is slow/clunky so it takes a few tries to get use to (there is a training room). My friend is pretty bad at platformer games, so it was funny watching him die from failed jump attempts multiple times. I'm a terrible person.You can play as 3 main characters, but you are able to capture/buy "souls" to transform into monsters and play as them until you want to switch or it gets killed (which then you return to your character as they were before you transformed). Using monster transformations makes getting through the game easier. Some monsters suck while others have really cheesy skill sets and/or incredible mobility (centaurs can jump very high and far). You can purchase/find items, but they are temporary (you lose them on death) so the only thing you really keep is money. The game also updates based on how many times the final boss was defeated (total of leadboard scores).Co-op mode is fun, but with friendly fire on (default setting) in this type of game I can see why only 2 players are supported. You would spend more time getting beat up by your teammates than the monster. Luckily, there is an option to turn off friendly fire with minor limitations (leaderboard related). Monsters can't hit each other unless charmed so I think it isn't fair getting mobbed esp in co-op (increased number of monsters boss/miniboss)if they all ignore your friend and decide to♥♥♥♥♥♥you instead. HINT: if you solo play in online settings make sure FRIENDLY FIRE IS ON so you can kill monsters you've charmed instead of waiting for it to wear off.BTW PEOPLE COMPLAIN ABOUT CONTROLS BEING INCOMPATIBLE. People give diffrent suggestions, but I personally use Joy-to-Key program. I didn't have to buy a new controller for the same controller I use for every game I play compatible or not.tl;drI got this two-pack for friend and myself; (EDITED) $12.50.2D Platformer fighting game with sufficient skill customization and able to level up. Supports local and Online Co-op.Has PVP for online and local.Game updates based on cumulative leaderboard score.Get a program  if your controller doesn't work with this game. (I use Joy-to-Key)Difficulty 6.5/10 (practice makes perfect!)Rating 8/10 (+1 Price, +2 Smooth Online Co-op experience, +3 Good game for its genre, +2 replayability)

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												More like a rogue-like fighting game than a metroidvania style game, which will probably throw a lot of people off at first.  You're going to need to give the enemies more attention than you're used to, and the controls will not be like those of a platformer.But if you're willing to put some effort into learning the controls, it can be a very challenging and fun title.  The art style and  atmosphere created make this one of my favorite games.  The enemies are interesting and well scripted, so that you'll need to learn their individual strategies and weaknesses in order to deal with them.  The three main playable characters have very different fighting styles and allow for customization of weapons, accessories and special moves.  These can synergize to give the player much more power when the right combinations are found.The levels are procedurally generated, so each playthrough you'll want to pay attention to the map layout to find the most desirable route.  The different difficulties make quite a bit of difference in AI ability, and you'll want to stick to the easy levels until you get the hang of it.

												The things you should know about this game:Only Personal inventory of one weapon and a couple trinkets, if you die you loose them, if you quit out, you loose themNo save, play the game beginning to end, or start over,It does have milestones "Towns" but you only start a new game in the town you nevver get to it through progressionYou level but I have no real clue why.Everything is expensive to buy, and since none of it stays when you die, the store in town is a whole lot of useless.Only one starting character unlock the other two.Stealing souls is like a shot in the dark, plus they go away too.In a nutshell, it is a classic game(No real innovation), demanding grinding and perfection.Yet, offering no real reward to gameplay. number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Abyss Odyssey is a weird little game. At first I wasn't too happy with it, because the game literally tells you nothing going in. However, after about a half hour or so it started to click - it's a a roguelike platformer with a combat focus, basically. I was expecting the combat to be similar to something like Marvel vs Capcom based on videos, but in reality it's much closer to Smash Bros, with normal and special attacks based on directional commands. Once you get the hang of it, taking down a bunch of dudes feels pretty satisfying. I strongly recommend getting the special cancel upgrades when you can, because it gives you a lot more freedom to play how you want.I also love the art and sound design - If you've played ACE Team's other games like Zeno Clash you know they have a tendency to get weird, but the atmosphere in AO skews much more towards "pleasantly trippy" than "uncomfortably disturbing" like parts of ZC did.  One complaint I have is that for a roguelike, the main difficulty isn't too hard - I beat the final boss on my second try, though it's worth mentioning the difficulty scales as you level up. Also, the devs just added a "Nightmare Mode," and it they're already tweaking game balance via patches. It sounds like ACE Team has every intention of continuing to update for months to come, so I'm definitely curious to see how the game changes in the future.  Worth a look if you like games like Spelunky.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
 Summary: A game that may not have the longevity to warrant comparisons to Rogue Legacy, but definitely has a unique battle system that relies more of slow but pointed movement. The combat system at its core felt like a good changeup for the genre as it reminded me of having influences from fencing, and it's complemented by a beautiful art style and a great soundtrack. The game does have content problems, as it's corridors and enemies do start to grow stale over time, especially in the layout department. However, combat surprisingly never felt TOO repetitive for me due to its mechanics, and I disagree with a lot of users saying that the controls are bad for the game: they perfectly fit in for what the combat was trying to do. In the end, the mixed rating on Steam really surprised me about Abyss Odyssey: I felt the game did give a great experience that stood out from others in the genre, and is definitely worth a look for fans looking for a slower, but more detailed combat experience in the end.  Gameplay Footage and Video Review: 


YouTube™ Video: Objection! : Abyss Odyssey 

			Views: 271		

			In the court of Gaming opinion, can Abyss Odyssey be acquitted from the accusations made against it? In this episode of Objection, we take a look at some of the biggest arguments against the game,...		

 Lists: +: Combat feels pointed and well refined with all the different characters and monsters that you can play as, and yet it working well for all of them. If you're looking for Smash/Rogue Legacy, it's not that, but something a bit different, where it punishes you for big mistakes.  Precision is rewarded well and I really enjoy that. You really do feel like you master combat in the game once you get a hang of it. Some claim the controls are bad for the game, and I have to say: nonsense. It works well for the kind of game that it was going for, that it complements the game in the right ways.  Like the basic storyline they go for here, despite it not being that big in the overall picture. Enough intrigue to make you want to know more. Interesting mechanic in the soldier picking up where the hero leaves off, being a bit underpowered but having to fight his way to resurrect the hero. Liked it. Characters feel unique despite seeing some of them before in other games of their series. Always loved these character designs, even the human ones.  Wonderful aesthetic with a great soundtrack makes a game that hits well with it's overall art style and unique 2D/3D models.-: Over time, the lack of variety in the environments will make the game feels repetitive. Could have used a lot more “random” events to spice things up over time.  Leveling feels unbalanced in the long run, as having higher levels seems to make the game significantly easier, or at least it feels like it. Wasn't having problems at all around level 50. There's some weird glitches that happen, and a reasonable slowdown at times when defeating enemies. It's not the most optimized of games, that's for sure.  Some double jumps can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥with the secondary characters in particular. Too little leeway at times can lead to a lot of frustration.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Was looking for a side-scrolling action game and got this as part of a bundle so decided to give it a shot despite the mixed reviews. How pleasantly surprised I was! The game doesn't take long to complete and once you get used to the somewhat clunky combat-system, it becomes quite enjoyable. Visually, the game is stunning and I was very impressed with what I saw. I honestly didn't know what to expect so that probably helped. Dying means losing all your equipment but you retain your skills and experience. The game also has a unique option of giving you a "second chance" where a soldier steps in to take over the fight once you are down (at least for me). From there, it becomes a frantic rush to stay alive and find the next altar to revive your fallen hero! It is a relatively easy game to pick up and one where you can end up spending more time than you had anticipated.Definitely worth getting when it goes on sale!

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												I do and I don't recommend this game. While starting out the controls felt clunky and heavy-ish, after some time in combat I understood that the way fighting was designed its just something you have to get used to. It does become more tactical, but in a sort of rock paper scissors advanced kind of way. Move in, are they blocking? I should throw or move away or throw a fireball to goad them into a dodge to catch them at the end of their animation. Which became more enjoyable as I continued playing the game.I didn't really play the other characters, however I was more concentrated on beating the game. If you're looking for a game to enjoy a playthrough and have a good experience based on that single playthrough, I don't recommend this game. However if you're looking for a game where you jump in, fight enemies for a while and enjoy a randomized dungeon experience through a bunch of playthroughs. I would recommend this game. I beat the game in two sittings and enjoyed the experience but its not a game that really sticks with me and makes me want to talk about it with everyone. If  someone was like "Hey I saw you play Abyss Odyssey on Steam, how is it?" I'd just be like "Its aight." and that's all. But it does feel like a good game for when I come home and just want to beat up some stuff with some strategy and don't want to put too much effort into. To sound like an old fogey gamer (which I might very well be at this point) the gameplay is reminiscent of games from the SNES era where you just played it and got used to the controls, clunky controls weren't something to be like "Screw this game." as long as the clunkiness worked with the gameplay. Then it was just getting used to how to play the game and finding the experience you were meant to enjoy because you had 5 more days with the rental and you beat all your other games already, also you just moved to the area and realized it was a neighborhood of grandparents mainly so you had no other kids to play with.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												This game kinda grew on me.I was first drawn to Abyss Odyssey because of its art style. Really enjoyed it and I think it’s one of its main distinctive features.At first, when I started playing, it felt a bit awkward, the controls (keyboard and mouse) felt a bit clumsy and chunky, and I was thinking "disappointed with a great looking game". But I got used really fast.After this adaptation period, no more felt awkward controls, all went smoothly.Added to really nice art style, Abyss Odyssey has enough variety to keep a player engaged for a few hours, in my case, 27 hours. It has lots of characters to play with, each with its play style, and the 3 main characters have different abilities to choose from and upgrade. The player starts by choosing one of this main characters to play with, but during the game he can capture the essence of fallen enemies and turn into them.The game structure is another of the features that caught my attention: on each playthrough, the player has the opportunity to play randomly generated rooms with different difficulty levels, to play special rooms, to play with different characters, to play against an assortment of enemies and to choose and upgrade your equipment, adding to replayability and longevity.All in all, Abyss Odyssey is a good action sidescroller, with great art style, interesting gameplay and design, and enough to keep a player engaged for a few dozen hours.On some side notes, it has achievements, which always add value to the game, and also competitive multiplayer, although mostly "dead" due to lack of players, which is fine by me, since I usually don't care much for MP features. I do get annoyed when games have achievements for MP, but in this case I found some friend on steam to help me with the game single MP achievement.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												I'm going to keep this very short. Abyss Odyssey is an okay game with a pretty neat art style.The combat seems complex with move cancels, blocks, dodges, normal attack, jumping attacks, special attacks, and the ability to combine them in interesting ways. It can be a little overwhelming when trying to keep track of all the movesets that you have to fight with and against. Every monster has their own movelist. The player also tends to have access to at least 3 movesets in a run if you're not switching out captured monsters often. The one bad thing about combat is facing which can become frustrating quickly. It can be sometimes difficult to face the correct direction, especially if the enemy walks just far enough to be on the other side of you and evade all your hits. The feeling can be amplified if there are multiple enemies around. I quickly became a big fan of any fast or sweeping/aoe attacks.You aren't just the character you select, you can be various monsters depending on your level since that determines which ones you can capture. If you die, you come back as a soldier that wields a weapon dependent on your main character until you hit a shrine or trigger a monster stage in-between areas. I saved up 25K gold and spent it on the wishing well to purchase a pretty cool halberd character with plenty of sweeping attacks that covered both sides. She's the one I could beat the game with since her normal attacks are pretty boss, although the monster that wears the sombrero really helped me out in the end. Some monsters feel much better than others and I enjoy playing as the good ones.Finally, I thought the story had an interesting Chilean flavor (journal pages), the environments were mostly nice (hazards sometimes blended in a little well), and the game is built around replayability if you like collecting monsters or enjoy the fighting system. The map is randomized for every fresh run. The only thing you keep is gold while weapons and equipment will go poof upon game overs.Abyss Odyssey is okay. You need to be willing to learn how the combat works. I definitely recommend dropping 25K in the treasure room (it's the gold room on the map) for the halberd character for an easier time.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Here you have quite an unique game.I could have played a lot of games, but there's occasionally one that could surprise me for its originality.It has a captivating story and setting, creatures are from Chilean lore or common imaginary, but they're presented with a new interpretation.- ... and one with some useful npc: they gave me impression of being part of the fictional world without the usual " just here for the player to pass by", and they have some good artworks too :D -It's an action platformer that seems to wink to a lot of different genres, here are some aspects: roguelike - you may find/buy objects but when you've reached endgame you will only keep your level, skill points and money; no savegame during a "run" of the dreamlike abyss;levels are randomly generated with each play. rpg elements - characters gather exp with kills or with a special encounter, gaining more HP and the ability to capture and transform in the various creatures (only one at a time) they could encounter, weapons have a single stat and attributes like fire, poison etc..fighting elements - each creature you may encounter is a force to recon with, because each character/creature/npc have its moveset so it's like a 2D fighting game when doing battles. This aspects shine as the principal one.Since it's relies so much on frenetic, quick and precise controls, like old days games, you need to be prepared to learn well how to use all the functions.Anyway it's simple to get used to the controls functions, but...It seems that some people had input delays on controls.I had the same issue and was really about to upset me.Anyway I understood that the reason for that delay was for my pc specs, so, lowering the resolution and removing effects with a bit of patience, trying, until the right one configuration was found.Keep in mind that this game works perfectly with a gamepad ( I use xinput compatible 360 pad), and is definitely high recommended.I have really enjoyed how works using the right analog stick for normal attacks, this function gives a sense of "fencing" to all the fights.About gameplay and replayability.Since it has roguelike elements it's intended to be played a LOT of times and it's quite enjoyable doing so, especially if you'll like the story since using one character will unlock new dialogs lines with the final boss.One appoint could be done for the lenght of each stage-level for being too short: once the player get accustomed to various   game elements one run could be done pretty fast, around 45 min.-It reminds me old school games I used to play that I could replay day after day beating each time the game.Using the main character made me recall the first Prince of Persia, maybe for the platform action and each fight was an actual duel-Anyway seems that more additional content will be done as well some adjustments for the options and configuration.Graphic and soundFluid animations, great pc/npc/creatures models, a lot of stunning background visible in distance (another unique aspect with some nice light effects) and a wonderful artwork set.Music themes change on levels, nice, but not its strenghtpoint, proper voiceacting.Recommended to those in search for an original story and atmosphere, visually appealing artworks, and a bite of old school gaming.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												Did you notice the 'Rogue-like' tag on the store page? i did not. So i thought this was a story driven beat em up game  just like earlier ACE team made Zeno clash games (awesome games btw) but now as a platformer. Well it really is a Rogue-like game and a very unique one. Is it any good? Depends. It is very hard. frustrating in fact. rage quits are never far away. But at the same time it got a very unique recipe for making you come back and have some more punishment. Unique. That's the word i will use to describe this game.  Everything about it is unique. I dont think i have ever played a rogue-like game that takes it's combat system from a real beat em up game and mixes it with flowing game play such as Dust:Elysian Tail. But unlike Dust in this game it is not possible to just mash the buttons and get a good combo. Getting 'in to the flow' in fights and timing are essential. Also getting the proper moves and really getting into things like 'juggling' or 'teching' or 'normal attack cancel into a special move' -stuff. Sound too much like a beat em up? Well no it's not that but you will need to learn these things. vice versa just being good at Rogue games will not cut it. But if you like Rogue games then this game will provide you with a nice challenge with it's learning curve so fans of both genres should at least check this game out. Be patient. Thats the one advice i give on this game. Be patient and learn. read guides if you must and train with the training doll.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												Disclaimer: Got this game for free from a friend's bundle code.Abyss Odyssey is a fighting game disguised as a beat 'em up/platformer/roguelike. You do the basic things one would expect from those latter 3 genres -- fighting heaps of disposable bad guys, hopping around on moving floors, and crawling through variable dungeons that change with each iteration. But it's the fighting game mechanics that will carry you. Your use of animation cancels, unforgiving parries, launches, juggles, and general purpose combo mastery will carry you. The better you are at these fighting game mechanics, the faster you'll progress. A solid player can beat the boss within a few hours. There's a lot more to accomplish including fleshing out all the heroes, capturing all the enemies in the cool extra-life soul-stealing system, and multiplayer and nightmare difficulty.So take this recommendation with a caveat. The price you get Abyss Odyssey at should reflect the extent to which you can explore the game's mechanical depth and it should reflect your willingness to play to completion. If Abyss Odyssey is a one-and-done game to you, wait for a sale that justifies 3 hours of play. If your fighter mechanics are solid and you tend to be a completionist, feel free to pick it up for retail price.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
TL;DR: Having played a few hours so far I can attest this game is fun if you like side scrolling beat 'em ups with rogue-like elements and is worth the price ($10 that I paid, but I would pay $15). You can progress in the normal game by using basic techniques and skills or you can excel and go for the harder stuff by really practicing advanced techniques.Non-TL;DR:Some cons:There really isn't a lot of balance when it comes to the enemy souls. Some dominate, others die way too easily. To be fair, though, some of this is based simply on how well you understand their playstyle. Some of them benefit from a semblance of button mashing, and others you will get horribly punished for trying that and require some finesse. Then there are those few that are just bad and need some work.The controls have some small issues, but overall I have experienced much worse. For one, the climb up ledges mechanic has really plagued me. I'm not sure if it's just me or if it others have the issue, but I find myself falling a lot more than I believe I should when I feel I was correct in my controls. That said, very few times (I'm looking at you fiery shadow pits) has it caused me any big issues. Most of the time it just impedes my speed in progress. Actual combat feels well except for some rare instances of your character not wanting to turn around as snappy as you might be used to in most games of this type. However, personally, I feel as though this was intended to keep people from being button mashy and spammy. As is, I think the item depth is a bit lacking. I am going to assume that the future will hold some updates that expand the library of items as well as souls so I am not too concerned with it right now.The environments, while pretty, sometimes feel a bit samey (and this is after only four hours of gameplay). I know this is a curse of rogue-like/procedurally generated games, but it should be mentioned all the same. A little more detailed variety could really spice things up.Some pros: The basic mode difficulty as it is now, is fair. I have gotten massacred quite a few times but also excelled quite a few times based almost completely on my performance with a bit of random thrown in for flavor. I have not tried Nightmare mode yet.The art style is beautiful.The music is great. I found myself grooving quite a few times while trouncing foes.I like having various souls and items show up randomly. It's fun having things not be the same all the time.The characters are all well designed, as well as the enemies. I have not found one yet that I disliked. Being able to respec your skills is a lot of fun and encourages experimentation and building for specific floors if you feel the need. (Small con: You can't respec your skill cancel orbs.)Final thoughts:Well worth the price I paid and with all the feedback from the community pouring in I expect it to get even better.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												If you want tight fighting game combat, this is not the game for you. However what this game lacks in smooth gameplay, it tries it's hardest to make up for in looks and variety. The game looks absolutely stunning, and the designs of the characters are varied and interesting. The different areas are all great, but I wish there was a little more variety in them. Once you've seen one particular "tileset" you've seen all the permutations of it.The combat, which should be the core of the game feels a little bit "floaty". This doesn't feel great for what is essentially a fighting game. Sometimes moves that look like they should be hitting just go through enemies completely, and this just makes the combat feel not that great at times. It's still serviceable and has a ton of depth since you can capture enemy souls and play as them, which is the main draw of the game. Each enemy has a pretty distinct moveset and while some are clearly better than others each enemy has their own style and this gives a ton of replay value for the game.This replayability is much needed, since the game is actually kind of easy. I played this both co-op and solo, and the solo experience actually felt a lot easier. Enemies are more passive when you are alone and usually come at you one at a time. While in co-op play you usually tend to get ganged up on and comboed by multiple enemies at a time which makes the experience frustrating at times.All in all amazing art and music, decent combat, fun exploration and good replayability make this an overall great experience.

												First, the art of the game caught my attention and after watching a few videos, I decide to give it a try. I was a bit disappointed at first b/c I was expecting something else (something like Dragon's Crown). However, after a few more hours, I am hooked. The game system remind me of Japanese dungeon RPG where you lose your progress and items when you die, but in this game, you get to keep the level/skills, money, and souls/characters for vs mode. Many have complaints about this mechanic in the forum, but I think it works just fine. Also, the game is designed for multiple play-through, so don't expect it to be long to reach the final boss (took me about an hour on the first try). Bunch of cheap asses). However, I hope the developer would tune/balance characters for the VS mode as time go by and hoping the game would be in FTG tournaments.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												It's a side scrolling action game with elements of a rogue-like and a platformer. Three playable characters, each with unique move list and a corresponding weapon. The game has some light equipment collecting and leveling, randomly generated dungeon lay outs and the ability to play as most enemies and bosses, once the player's character reaches the apropriate level and capture them with a particular move. The combat system seems heavily inspired by Nintendo's smash brothers series. on that note, the game supports two player co-op and feature a four-player versus mode. The multiplayer segment is probably the biggest selling point for a metroidvania trying to differntiate itself from the restAfter you get the hang of the game, progressing to the bottom of the dungeon is not particularly difficult, and can be accomplished relatively quickly. at that point of the game, emphasis changes from merely progressing through the dungeon to smaller objectives: collecting all note book peices (items that convey the game's lore) leveling and improving your character's equipment, and collecting all playable enemies.  While its fun, it does become tiresome quickly- the experiance is short but polished enough to reccomend. It helps that the game's art, music, and scant lore are all fantastic.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Rougelite Muramasa. Three characters, many more monsters (which you can possess), and a huge, procedurally-generated dungeon. There's a lot to love here. The visuals are gorgeous, as well. It plays more like a fighting game than a beat-em-up (it even has a cancelling system!) but most of the moves have a lot of ending lag so the controls can seem a bit sluggish. I tend do only do aerial attacks because the ending lag is cancelled when you land (pro tip!). The game can get a bit repetative and easy after sinking several hours into it. I guarantee you won't get far at level 1, but by level 50 you won't even need to put much planning into your route or items. There is also a "nightmare" difficulty, but I haven't tried that out yet. I would have appreciated more character variety and faster-paced fighting, but I like what they gave me anyway. Definitely worth a play.Oh, and bring a controller.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												I must admit that I love every game published by Atlus, regardless of their genre or developer. This one makes no exception. It's basically a 2D version of Demon's Souls (not to diminish the designer's work, it's just to give you an idea of what kind of game to expect) with random generated areas. Very good music, wonderful art, lot of playable characters and combat styles. Unfortunately it's not a masterpiece though: the combat mechanics could have been improved and since the game is basically a fighting game this is a bit of a problem. I'm not saying that the combat is bad like I've read on many reviews, far from it. It just could have been a bit better, some animations are a bit stiff, sometimes you feel like some moves link (or not) for random reasons, sometimes you don't  feel the combat as you should and some fights are a bit cheap, depending on the combination of moves of your character compared to the opponent. In conclusion, while the game has some defects, as a whole I can recommend it without reservations, given that you like hard and demanding games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												A long time Coming     Well, what can i say?  This game has some excellent qualities, and holds on to you for a bit.  One of the greatest side-scrolling hack and slash games' I've found for those thirsty for some hack and slash, without the over-the-top gore and special effects, not to say it doesnt have it's own special effects.  Probably one of the most beautiful side scrollers I've played in a loooong time, the environments are either lush, or barren, dependening how deep into the abyss you get?  There is a Beautiful Soundtrack that enhances the mood tenfold, alot of thought was put into it, with beautifully instense piano clips, and music fitting the mood, perfect for the environments you find yourself in.  The Environments follow the old platforming standart of Earth,Wind,Water, and Fire, which are gorgeously Illustrated, with deep levels of parrallax scrolling.  You can sit and pick out details in the background that look like you could just reach out and grab them, not quite on the level of Trine or Trine 2, but beautiful, and effective nonetheless.       Now here is the news on combat, you can either play this game just mashing the buttons and not get as far, but more than likely, you are going to have to develop some sort of strategy, at some point,  The game basically ramps up the difficulty to make it more of a challenge when you rank up, and it does subtle changes to the AI when the game realises you are dying waay too much.  The combat system is pretty nice it uses the Xbox 360 controller very well, all of the buttons are taken into account from the beginning.  I'll let you discover the combos on your own, it'd be a spoiler to take away the fun of discovering how deep the control scheme actually is.  I actually found it good enough to go into the "Practice" gamemode, This game wants you to beat it, but not too quickly.  Therein lies the good and the bad, the story is paper thin, which allows you to basically hack and slash your way through it without thinking too deeply, and adds a little emptiness and sorrow to the game, without detracting from it's character.   It sometimes gets real hard to navigate through the abyss you hit a "hard" room and it can be all over in one encounter (I.E. the Life that you enter the Abyss with Is all you get), which isn't bad, but you don't want to give up even if you only have 400+ health out of 2200, and you can still pick up characters that you defeat. and add them to your inventory to use in a pinch.  It's all really fun, and frustrating, which I believe it strikes a perfect balance.       In Closing, i highly recommend this game to any hack and slash platform lovers, it will not dissappoint.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												First thoughts: Street Fighter combat meets classical Art Nouveu. Finely drawn stills with clumsy polygonal animation and stunted voice acting. Welcome to a rogue-lite adventure where the combat may drive you mad, or be your cup of tea. A well planned introduction that is going to steep you in combat mechanics you either have the reflexes for or are willing to practice to obtain.Having never been competent at fighting games (I beat Street Fighter II on the SNES but once at difficulty 'III'), I admit I'm in over my head and instantly grateful for the weapon and moveset upgrading system. If I've any chance at all, that alone is to be thanked.This is a lucious game, and there's a lot to love, if you're a genre fan. Awkward voiceovers can be overlooked, the base character leveling system gives less skilled players a chance. Unfortunately the character animations are quite stilted and lack the polish that would have better integrated them into the classic, 1890s art style.For an indie, this is an impressive start but for full price this is too much to ask for casual players. This is no minor distraction, but a lore rich, gorgeously presented nightmare. Know your quarry before spending your coin.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												I was excited for this game when I heard one curator describe it as "metroidvania/super smash brothers". That's not really accurate at all. The game was clearly designed to evoke that exact comparison, though - a lot of mechanics, the art style, and even the controls are largely cribbed from the above influences.Abyss Odyssey has controls of Super Smash Brothers, but does not play at all like Super Smash Brothers. It plays like a traditional fighter: slower, methodical, combo-based. Abyss Odyssey has the look of Castlevania, but does not play at all like Castlevania. You do not explore, and the dungeon isn't really that interesting or well-designed (indeed, it's not designed at all, because it's randomly generated). I still like this game for what it is, but I do feel that the hype is misleading. If you're interested in a semi-randomly-generated sidescrolling fighter game, this is the perfect game for you!
