content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												tl;dr: The combat is laudable but still unsatisfying. The feel is off and there's little room to demonstrate superior skill against the enemies because they are all playable characters and thus can do anything you can. The dungeon and story are charmless. Interesting game, worth a taste, not a classic.I dream of battling huge steroided up jerks. The huge guy lets out a roar before his swing, I dodge, counter attack, he flashes before I finish my combo, I dodge out of it just in time to avoid a fearsome counter-attack. Really, give me an attack button and a satisfying dodge roll and I am a happy camper in most games.Actually, scratch that, turns out I need a bit more than just Attack and Dodge. Odyssey has both in spades and it is not quite enough for me.Odyssey is a side-scrolling brawler roguelike-ish game with a random dungeon and permadeath and all the usual fixin's as well as persistent XP growth and move collection and what-not, the usual sort of thing you expect of the recent indie action roguelike trend. The combat is somewhere south of Smash Bros and east of Bloodrayne Betrayal (Only not nearly as awful.) Your moveset is limited, attack+direction, special+direction, but there is some combo potential here, though a lot of the fighting feels a little stiff and wooden. Watching enemies get up is a Chilean passtime, it seems; you'll do a lot of that. You have a limited number of dodge cancels before they have to recharge (See Valdis Story only less cool.) and can become pretty much any enemy in the game.Yep, every single enemy is a playable character, and that actually feeds into a problem I have with the game.Back to my example at the start, I am reading the boss's attack patterns and reacting. I'm rewarded for learning the system and striking at the right time. The enemies in Odyssey, however, are really all just variations of your character with generally less openly useful moves. They block, dodge (Especially your projectiles), and can attack without warm-up most of the time. This means that you just have to take a lot of unavoidable damage each encounter just because there is no safe way through. Fighting your equals creates a cute dance, but it feels a lot more like battling Street Fighter AI rather than facing down Vergil.But then there's a reason you're taking all that damage. Between your main character, his/her backup soldier, and the enemy you can morph into, you have three whole life bars. Match this up with persistent leveling and you can more or less kiss balancing goodbye. This will sound like heresy but I cleared the dungeon on my second try. For my reward, I unlocked the second town to start from, though I still have two characters to unlock as well as a third town. I only ever faced one midboss (Though he was absolutely no deviation from the standard enemies in combat style. Even the warlock himself felt like I was back to jump-kicking Akuma over and over.)I'll definitely go back to the game, but in the end I will likely forget it sooner rather than later.This Warlock has some really boring dreams, to boot. Everything is muted, murky colors and all the enemies are just kinda ugly dull pitiable mutants.Also, I have paid minimal attention to the story, and in return it has demanded precious little of my attention. I applaud the minimalist approach, though the huge dreary ugly world down here and all the story hints suggests we're going to be asked to pity that so tragic warlock because it's so dramatic to not have a villain (Really, having a proper villain seems like it would be the most shocking thing some games can do these days, but I digress. That's not Odyssey's problem...). Which actually brings me to a point I don't like about the story: You play as one of the few figments of the warlock's dreams that is not a slavering demon trying to kill everyone. You are not shocked by anything you see because you're a part of it. You can't die either, so you just keep coming back and trying again.But the soldiers in the game are human beings just trying to fight the monsters of the abyss, protect their families, and when you fall, despite your immortality, they still will swoop in to do their damndest to save you. Hell, in my last clear, the soldier was the one who defeated the warlock (Only to poof out and be replaced by my character for the ending cutscene. What a snub!).So you are playing an blob of memories with neither a personality nor a stake in this conflict and the people relegated to the sidelines are genuine heroes with personalities and fears who are to the last man engaging in wholly noble and heroic acts of holding the line against hordes of ugly monsters, all afraid, but all driven by duty. Someone at some point thought that it was better to tell the story of the Warlock's childhood trauma or whatever instead of the story of these gents. Good job on that.If the story is somehow more interesting than NOW ON A VERY SPECIAL EPISODE OF ALL MY WARLOCKS, I welcome hints or even, properly marked, spoilers in the comments if you feel the need to convince me reading rather than playing the game is worthwhile.

number of helpful: 9 of 23 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I will continue to add and change this review as I play the game more. 5/10Abyss Odyssey promises to be so much, and yet delivers so little... I wondered at first why this game was offering a pre-purchase discount, for over 2 weeks before it's launch, well now I know why... The game promised to have an in depth, well thought combat system, but immediately, it is very stale, boring, and simple. I bought the lie that this was a side-scroller "castlevania-eqsue" game with a unique "fighting style" combat system, and I was very disappointed. The worst is how an enemy who falls down is immune to all damage... You spend more time waiting for enemies to get their $%@ off the ground than you do actually fighting.This game is fun to look at, decently entertaining to run around in and meet the characters, but it is just simply not what the devs promised it to be. Now that the truth is out, I will say that this game IS very pretty. The artwork is awesome whenever you speak with a character. The art style is unique and obviously latin-inspired (of course). If for no other reason, buying this game simply to meet the characters and look at the artwork would make it feel semi-worth. Pros:Beautiful artworkDecent Vocal ActingFun to get a new weaponVarious and diverse enemiesFun to look atCons:TERRIBLE combat systemUnintuitive abilitiesNo inventory system (cannot keep/sell old weapons/items)Forced to watch enemies flail on the ground My Inital reactions:*Have to pay in game gold to save the game and set checkpoints... *Enviroments are a bit stale, but still pretty detailed*Artwork is gorgeous in the chat scenes*Character feels a bit wonky when moving/jumping, but especially when landing, it's very odd...*Initial combat system is pretty to look at, but feels completely unintutitive, I sincerely hope this changes as the game goes on, because right now, the combat system feels terrible*It's not a big deal, however, I feel people should know you have to unlock the other characters to play as them. I wanted to jump right into the shadow monk (or whomever) however I cannot until I play more. Just a heads up.*Game just came out, so it's not 100% surprising, however, I've only played for 30 minutes so far, and have ran into 2 glitches already. 1 made the prologue impassible, had to restart, 2 game froze on screen switch*If an enemy falls on the ground, you cannot hurt them, or do anything to them... You have to wait for them to get back up... This feels odd and makes every single fight boring... You can't do much but hit twice, watch them fall, and just wait.... You may jugle enemies in the air, but the system isn't constructed well enough for that to work out in a dependable way...

												I got this game free, and yet I still feel ripped off. The gameplay is slow, awkward, and clunky. The character controls don’t feel precise, and the UI is lacking any kind of useful information. The story is very boring each level is just your progression to the bottom of the abyss, and it provided little motivation to continue through as I didn’t feel connected to any of the characters. The levels are procedurally generated, but this didn’t help the repetitiveness at all, because every time you die the game resets you back to the beginning. The clunky combat, forgettable story, and grindy levels make this feel more like a chore than a game.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Levels are boring. They are all square block mazes. And they're not even hard mazes (logically). Sometimes the game screws you over and you cannot reach a certain point because it's too high (even with crouch-jump when possible).Often the sluggish controls prevent you from moving in the direction you want to go or from grabbing onto a ledge or from landing on a platform.Combat is sluggish and cancel points don't renew over time. There is no telegraphing of enemy moves either.You best option is to discover bad patterns in the enemy's AI such as dodging right into a low sword attack after you fire a projectile into them. Often you can face away and just do a crouching attack which just kinda rolls back and hits them.Basically the combat is not fun. It's too sluggish to control, and you resort to exploits which is not fun either.To sum up, control is not fun (moving and attacking), exploration is not fun, there is no action, it's just not a deep or fun game.Also, when you defeat a shopkeeper he does not drop the loot he was carrying.Why is there an option to attack him when it's a waste of time?

number of helpful: 2 of 12 people (17%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												So what happens when you take Castlevania Symphony of the Night... or more accurately Castlevania Aria / Dawn of Sorrow and combine it with Dark Souls clunk? Well let me answer that for you... You get a game about travelling in to a procedurally generated abyss delving deeper and deeper to kill some demon warlock Freddy Kruger guy, who's nightmares are your reality. In fact, you're not even real because he dreamt you up... except you want to kill him... that's what kind of game you get... yeah.So this game tries way too hard to be epic and it just fails on just about every front. The art style is the only thing this game has going for it and it's just a shame it was wasted on such a giant turd like Abyss Odyssey. It's as if all the production value went in to the art style and none of it in to the game development, plot or music because it was all forgettable.It's nothing new you haven't already seen, the point being is a lot of the game play mechanics are drab, boring and redundant... let me explain:It's a rouge like game, where no dungeon you enter is ever the same twice... except that's kind of a lie because every area is almost exactly identical to the last, aside from some buzz saws and flowers trying to kill you.You basically travel down a linear path and encounter a branching point here and there. These branching paths quickly lead to a dead end with a treasure chest or check point of some kind. Usually when there's nothing there I do what any veteran Casltevania player would do and smack the wall. 20% of the time there's a hidden area with a shop keeper or paltry weapon hiding behind it... No meat though, I probably would of enjoyed a nice Castlevania roast beef here and there but no... it's usually just some crap.Another thing about this game is how lazy the direction is... I mean, procedurally generated dungeons for a game with this kind of art style? With all the effort put in to the art direction you figured they would of came up with some cool level designs and boss design concepts and made an actual game... you know, one where the developers have to always be one step ahead of themselves so players can't sequence break the game... either way it's wasted potential.The game itself gets dull and tired way too quickly. It has unlockable characters and starting points but you need to rely heavily on luck... Okay basically everything resides on your luck, as well as time put in to the game.I beat the game once, unlocked some floaty chick with a spear who has a jelly fish for a companion (Yeah is this making you cringe yet? I was rolling my eyes the entire time... what pretentious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is this any way?) There's also a heavy weapon user who looks a lot like Tyrael from the Diablo franchise (because THAT was purely a coincidence) and he's randomly unlocked by beating random bosses you encounter... random, random, random ....so have fun with randomly doing that.Another thing that bothered me was the limited inventory space ... of 4 whole spaces. Enjoy managing poison antidotes, mana potions, health potions and check point tokens when you can basically only carry 1 of each item. The number one biggest waste of resources though that made up most of the game's mechanics, or should I say gimmick, was the ENTIRE enemy capture system... I mean WTF is the point of all this? All the enemies I caught were even clunkier and weaker than my main character.... none of them had any really cool abilites and were all difficult to control... It's as if the developers were saying: "Hey switch to this centaur thing if you want to die... like right now... yeah there ya go, you're dead now, hope that helped."I never understood why the game forced you in to sequences where you had to play as random enemies either, other than to basically get their spirit afterwards... as some kind of reward? Great, thanks for THAT. Most of the time I had something better to do, like NOT playing as a worthless enemy character.Either way the game's plot and premise is a cryptic mess, just like Dark Souls, so I guess they got the worst possible aspects of that series right... Clunky gameplay, in order to artificially increase the difficulty of the game; and a cryptic plot so it confuses the player in to thinking their mind has been "blown'.... except... no it hasn't, this game is just stupid and you're trying too hard to make sense of all of it...It's a 5 out of 10 at best... it tries, it fails... go play Castlevania SotN... It's just a better game as well as the godfather of the genre... When are developers going to learn you can't reinvent perfection?

												Abyss Odyssey, a beat 'em up with randomly generated levels in the style of Metroidvanias, is not perfect in its current state, but provides a very good fighting engine, variety of enemies, wonderfully realized presentation, and straight up addicting gameplay. In addition, the game is still under active development, and is seeing improvements to the fighting and movement engine as we speak.My biggest problem as of right now is how easy the game can be. If you're a fan of fighting games, I'll tell you right now, go straight to Nightmare difficutly.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												Smash Bros. Melee had a baby. A weird tentacle baby who plays with monsters from Chiloé mythology. She's a descending roguelike who falls into an ever-changing abyss. More importantly, this is definitely Smash Bros. Melee's kid. She plays just like her daddy.Fighting game aficionados might complain that Abyss Odyssey doesn't go a ton deeper beyond combos and cancels. Roguelike fanatics may lament that Abyss Odyssey is too forgiving with runs average over half an hour (and lack any mid-progress save). But Abyss Odyssey isn't a Smash-like and it isn't a roguelike. It's something else: a tentacle baby.If you had a baby born with tentacles — and you were a good parent — you'd love her and make her feel at home. You would learn the best practices in tentacle care, and taunt gaping onlookers when they stare. Abyss Odyssey is that tentacle baby, and I hope you love her at least half as much as I do.8.5/10For more: http://plus10damage.com/blog/2014/8/13/smash-bros-tentacle-baby-abyss-odyssey-review

												I've seen a lot of negative feedback about the controls in this game.  True, there was a moment or two in the beginning where I almost swung my controller at my monitor like a chromed up War Boy with a mace.  But a few things happened that allowed me to beat the game after a few hours of play.  1) I somehow stumbled upon the monk character.  Everything is better once you get that cloaked, knee-padded savior.  I also liked Pincoya (the other unlockable character) and her spear.  2) I read up a bit about the game and learned about Cancel points.  Invest your level up points in those before anything else. 3) It turns out that button mashing is still relevant in fighting (style) games.  But to be fair, it's mostly parry mashing in this game.  You still need to learn the controls.10/10 would roll the controller against their forehead if it meant beating a horde of enemies.

												Argghhh.... That game... it's great and annoying at the same time. The thing about ACE team (the creators of the game), is that they make games with HUGEEEEE potential, yet they fall when it comes to gameplay and basic things. theoretically, their are games are AMAZING, but when it comes to the actual gameplay, you realize that they had a great plan that has gone to waste (same with Zeno Clash sadly).Abyss Odyssey is an awesome challenging game, that falls down when it comes to the combat and momvment. the combat is really repetive and boring, as you spam pretty much everything, while trying to doge and avoid pretty much everything.On the other hand, the art style, the music and the voice acting (yeah, thats right, unlike the voice acting in Zeno Clash - the voice acting in Abyss Odyssey is actually pretty good!) are all awesome, it's just that the combat is really frustrating.Well, the bottom line is - a great game, with huge potential (just as Zeno Clash has huge potential), but somthing went horribly worng along the way. meh, such a shame.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												A clunky fighter rogue-lite hybrid that, while decently fun despite he game handling like all your controller inputs were first translated by a monkey and then handed off the game developers who then decide whether or not your button press occurred or not, pretends to have much more depth on offer than it actually possesses. Collecting enemy souls isn't really that big of an appeal, they handle differently but each enemy type has one or two combos or moves that are just much better than the others and I find it difficult to want to invest time into learning how to handle this game knowing that my reward for high skill play is more monsters to learn. Since the only thing you keep are levels and levels don't offer a significant enough increase from level to level the game feels the same the first time you beat and every time after that. You'll be strategically choosing monster souls based on what is and isn't good or what you do and don't know how to play which doesn't really encourage learning new ones even if the game throws a bonus stage with a random monster at you after every boss (actually this can be more annoying than exciting, having to learn a whole new moveset to fight a mob or two is actually pretty frustrating even if there isn't an actual penalty for losing.)I want to like this game but the RPG and rogue-lite elements are limited, monster collecting doesn't appeal to me as it only serves to add a flimsy excuse to learn more about a game whose versus lobbies are deader than the extinct species list, and the storyline is only a bit interesting (less so when you realize you don't have any actual influence on it and reading about it doesn't actually give you any real benefit beyond a decently arranged story.) It's a decent game but it can only ever be decent when it is so riddled with flaws and the fact that the main menu contains an advertisement is just icing on the cake.I can't recommend this purchase, I like it but it isn't where it would have to be for me to say you should pick this one up. If you really want to learn a clunky fighting game system so you can fight the same 12-15 enemies over and over then go right ahead but I'm not going to be the guy encouraging you to do it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Abyss Odyssey is a platform based fighting game with a bit of story, a randomized map, and a whole lot of crazy. A major facet of the game is that death is not the end; not necessarily even in each playthough. When the main character, one of either Katrien, a dead dude with hands but no body, or a sea goddess, dies, they are simply replaced by a soldier (still playable, of course) who can revive the main at certain alters. Only when the soldier dies must you restart. However, death only costs you your progress down and your current one items. Level, exp, and gold are kept.    This game has a special mechanic that adds one more layer in. The main can use a special skill and rip the soul from an enemy, gaining the ability to transform into any enemy, including all bosses. Dying as a monster turns you back to the main, adding another layer of life. Which you will need because the monsters are brutally unmercifully good at beating you to a pulp. The AI is intelligent and each monster knows its strengths. If a monster is fast but weak and you shield, it'll wait for a hard hitter to show up and they will tag-team you to death.    The story (for characters, primarily. There isnt much of a plot.) and art of the game are amazing. The story is that a powerful warlock is in a asleep in a coma or something, and his nightmares are materializing in the real world. As one of his dreams, you are trying to stop him. Characters and monster are primarily from old Chilean myth and folklore and also a considerable amount from the Christian bible, plus many from various other worldwide myths, all with the wonderful wackiness of ACE. Plus there is also a crossover character from Zeno Clash now.Pros:Great visuals, music and designs.Every character/enemy is playable.Either way:Difficulty. The game is brutal. There is no easy mode or tutorial. Only hard or harder. I like that, but not everyone does.Enemies are really smart and know you, so you have to know and exploit them. Finding ways to successfully spam attacks is generally rewarded with not dying. You can do it, but so can the enemies, so it could go either way.Animation cancelling is a major mechanic. This means that learning combos through hard trial and error is the best way and messing one up can mean a lost battle due to long animations. The mechanic is really cool though, so again, either way.Cons:Controls can be a tad floaty, but its not that bad.Soldiers cannot jump as high as other characters, and I am bad at getting places with them. This is far more fruatrating than it sounds.Verdict:Excellent game. I really enjoy(ed) it. If you've never played a fighting game, or don't like them, or you're really bad, then this isn't the game for you. However, it is excellent for those who are willing to climb its learning curve.Notes: This is my first review. My apologies if I've messed absolutely everything up and offended everyone in the general vicinity. Also, my playtime is very inaccurate. I've played it offline most of the time. Supposedly the multiplayer is good, but I haven't bothered with it yet.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Short version:Pros:+satisfying combat+beautiful visuals+rogue-lite gameplay with some persistent progression+procedurally generated levels+unique fighting style for each playable unit+worthy of multiple playthroughs +coopCons:-simple goal with little story-fairly easy if you're good at this kind of side scrolling action-controls are somewhat clunky at times-a single play through is relatively short. game designed to be replayed (this can be a pro for some people i guess, since each play through does feel quite unique due to the randomly generated levels)-no online versus modeThis game's controls feel a little bit clunky, but I don't think that takes away from the gaming experience too much. Once you get used to the controls, the combat system feels quite satisfying. It has enough depth and encourages varying moves. You can perform special cancel to chain up combo, throw enemies who keep on guarding, do a 360 degree attack against those who get behind you etc. Overall, the fighting mechanism actually feels quite like something you'd expect in a fighting game.Each hero and other unit that you get to control has a unique move set. While some are arguably better than others (when playing as enemy units), They're still all interesting and fun to play as.Coop is also fun. I always embrace games that include the coop feature. If you have a friend who to play with you, definitely check this out.Gameplay wise, this game has a lot of rogue-lite elements. Levels are procedurally generated, and they offer a unique experience for every playthrough. Everytime you die, you'd have to restart from the beginning. The entire dungeon has to be cleared in one go and there is no in-dungeon saving. Also, if you die, all the items you're carrying are also gone. However, you do get to keep your levels, gold, and unlocked abilities, so there is a persistent progression. Because of the randomly generated levels and the uniqueness of each character, this game is certainly worthy of multiple playthroughs.The visuals are beautiful. Backgrounds have an unusal amount of details for any randomly generated level.However, there isn't a lot of story. the majority of the gameplay centers on combat and platforming with some exploration for hidden rooms and loot. A single playthrough is also relatively short, which is something i don't mind since i can replay it multiple times and still get a different experience in each playthrough. However, if you don't like replaying, then this might something you'd have to think about.The game has a local versus mode, but puzzlingly it doesn't have online versus (but it does have online coop).Overall, the game is fun, especially if you have a friend to play it with. Even if not, it is still worth getting for the single player expereince because of the randomly generated levels, which add a lot of replay value.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												+ visually striking, beutiful art style, and great animations.+ soundtrack, fits the feeling of the game well.+ combat, its deep for a 2D platformer.+ rouge-like elements, when u die it is not a game over, u respawn back at the begining with starter items and all the gold u had at the time of death, and the other charecters react to that as it fits the story.  use the gold u collected before dying to get better gear to help u progress, buy tokens to set respawn points deeper in the dungeon, or save up to get better gear the next time u die.+ interesting setting (I have not completed the story due to the game being hard as nails for me, but i did get to the lowest part of the dungeon and have played enough to comperhend most elements of the game)~ the dungeon areas r randomized every time u die and respawn at the begining, i find that fun as it adds variety to the game, but some may find it annoying as the area diffeculties r also randomized.~ diffeculty, u cant control it, each area in the dungeon has a diffeculty setting that is randomized unpon death regardless of how deep is that area.- skills and leveling up, adding points to a certain skill doesn't seem to have much of an effect on the skill, and leveling up doesn't feel like it affects u that much.  and the fact that u can only have 3 skills upgraded and leaveing the other 2 without the effect of the upgrads can be annoying to some.- learning curve, the game poorly explains all its mechanics early on, especially the combat combos and leveling up.- length, the dungeon can be done in a very short amount of time if u have the personal skills and/or powerfull enough equipment, its the rouge-like nature of the game that add gameplay length.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												This game is great. At first it can seem pretty difficult, but it's a game that requires some level of mastery. The way the combat system works is very similar to Super Smash Bros. There are shields, rolls, grabs, air dodges, directional attacks and aerial directional attacks. It handles differently though. It might take some time to get used to it even if you are familiar with Smash Bros. The campaign mode is like a randomly generated metroidvania with varying paths, monsters and bosses. There are multiple playable characters with all different skills, weapons, and movesets. You can even capture and switch between playing as your current character and a monster. The only negative things I can say about this game is 1) grabbing ledges is awful. You have to be really specific about how you approach the ledge. In some situations this can cost you a lot of health. 2) Sometimes you can get overwhelmed and wrecked by a group of enemies and/or stage hazards. They'll combo you to death if they attack you at the same time and get the first hit off. 3) Unavoidable hazards. There are some hazards that seemed too long to jump over. At least I couldn't make it with a double jump and dash/airdodge. I had to jump in and get poisoned. That's all the issues worth mentioning though. It's really good overall.

												I got Abyss as part of a humble bundle, but I got the bundle, in part, because I wanted a good game to play with my steam controller.  I am not very familiar with dungeon, rogue-like or brawler type games.  But I really like this game.  I haven’t quite beaten it but i’ve faced off with the final boss 3 times now.  ProsGood visual style, excellent art.  Another game proving that video games are a legitimate media-art form.  Controls seem fluid, easy to use.Interesting setting and story.The game is really unique and interestingThe three paths system of difficulty seems like a great system.ConsI don’t like that I lose my items when I die.  I know this is “rogue-like” but I wish there was a little more character progression.I wish the texture res was higher, OR that there was better texture filtering.  My characters have jaggies around them.Your incentivised to play as your backup garud character when you enter the final chamber as your main character will then be resurrected with full health.  There seem to be 3 different weapon classes and as such I cannot pick up weapons that are hard-won 2/3rds of the time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Yeah, this hit all the right buttons for me.Abyss Odyssey is a beat 'em up game with fighting game mechanics and loot grabbing - it has platform levels that change every playthrough, loaded with traps and secret rooms.Bad- controls are wonky. it's set up to attack left and you have to face right again and then press right to go in that direction. Some of the characters are limited because they are too big for an area or, in the case of the first soldier, cannot climb walls at certain heights. It's pretty flawed in these specific control problems. Most people cannot overlook this (thus the mixed Steam reviews) and I don't blame them.Good - but what shines in this game is the art, animation and design. The whole drips with polish and satisfying visuals in the art style of Art Nouveau masters like Mucha. The characters are strange and interesting with amazing movesets and fantastic animations - some of the pick-up enemies are more fun to play than the three main characters! The story is facinating Chilean myth with a bizarre twist that makes the mood eerie and one of a kind.Basically, if the controls were patched, this would be one of my favorite games, no doubt about it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Nice blend of roguelike, platformer and beatemup genres. You are able to capture defeated enemies' souls and play as those creatures yourself switching between them and your main char on the go giving you immense tactical possibilities.  Yes, ALL of the enemies in the game have a full arsenal of standard, forward, high, low, jump etc attacks in both fast+weak and slow+strong variations. Dashes, grabs, rolls, blinks, magic projectiles, spinning AOE and vomiting poison make combat both varied and challenging. Unfortunately, all this gorgeousness comes at a price: instead of Metroidvania-styled gameplay Abyss Odyssey is way too much linear and kinda lacks other content. The whole game is just a succession of randomly-generated beutiful 'biome' arenas that consist of a single vertically-oriented long corridor with a few dead end branches that have loot in them. More often than not when you reach a predetermined point in the arena enemies just spawn offscreen and you are locked in a small 1-2 screen sized battleground until you defeat them or die trying sorta JRPG-style. Apart from that and a handful of NPCs that train you or sell you stuff there is nothing to interact with. Don't get me wrong, Streets of Rage+Megaman roguelike is a welcome thing, but i'd prefer a +5-10$ in a price tag and a bit more content to deepen gameplay a bit (DLC maybe?).As for drawbacks, kb+mouse controls were a bit clunky, but now devs seem to have fixed everything and I was able to beat the game fwo times out of three tries while I haven't been able to beat it even once before due to unresponsive controls so I got rekt in harder levels because of slow character response. Also devs got a tiny bit lazy and out of a few dozens of enemy types (ALL PLAYABLE!) a couple are just a reskinned or posessed versions of your own characters, doubling as minibosses every now and then, but there is a good variation of unique bosses too though so it's not that bad.All in all a nice game i'd recommend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												TLDR: Very short game (4hrs or less) with great astetics and premise but an end result that is not worth the price. Consider only  if it is on sale by 75% or more, you like linear dungeon crawlers and  ONLY  if you own a controller. Otherwise stay clear.Full review:First of all, no, this is not a non recommendation due to the controls as it seems to be the case for a lot of other Steam reviews for this game. I actually found the controls to be pretty good and easy to learn ON A CONTROLLER (do NOT play this game otherwise, it IS a nightmare to play using the keyboard).Gameplay is pretty interesting, mainly thanks to the movement and attack controls which make even the very first enemies you encounter a decent challenge. However it can also get a bit too repetitive when most of the enemies follow a very similar pattern and you can even do the same tactics to defeat them, even to the point where you can stun-lock them on endless grab-throw moves ("final boss" included).I really love the asthetics and theme of this game, the artwork and spine-chill lovely music really gave me the good old Castlevania vibes. Even the voice acting feels like top quality with its few dialogues (that guitar playing skelleton chilling = GG). The big negative point why I cant really recommend this game, is the fact it is very, VERY short. Barely 4 hours in, as a below average skill player and I already cleared the 3 entrances to the Abyss, unlocked the 3 playable characters and gathered pretty much all of the "journal pages". There is nothing left to do other than probably try get a couple achievements if I was ever interested on those.Another letdown is that while the game presents you with what could be a very complex and interesting developing story about the origin of the abyss and of the characters you play as, it ends up being mostly told on the previously mentioned journal texts you can find after killing enemies and from what little dialogue there is each time you reach the Warlock. You kill the final boss and what do you get?  a pretty background and a "Yay, you did it! But guess what? the Warlock is still alive! Play again!" kind of message.  Nothing more, regardless of how many times you do it.If you see this game super cheap (75% discount or so), you feel like playing a very linear dungeon crawler and you own a controller, I'd say go for it and give it a try not expecting much, I had fun playing it but its flaws really outweight the good stuff unfortunately and at this price, there are a lot of far better games out there.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Genre: Fighting-RougelikeOverall rating: 86%Gameplay: 17/20Sound/Music: 9/10Graphics: 4/5 - Art design: 5/5Controls: 3/5Replay value: 5/5Gameplay; It's a fighting/platformer game with rouge-like elements. Combat works just like in a fighting game, every character/enemy has a proper move set, but instead of just a one screen arena, you have to fight through a randomized dungeon with multiple floors and paths. The game has around 40 characters, three of them are main characters with the ability to capture enemy souls. This is one of the key features of the game, because once you capture a soul you can use that enemy/boss in the game. There are some ballance issues with this though, some are near worthless some are op and this can impact versus mode. However it's not just a regular figthing game with platforming. The game has co-op and an inventory system, your main charactes can level up and gain skill points to strengthen moves they have found.Sound/Music; Music is excellent, sometimes reminds me of Castlevania, it creates a good atmosphere for the levels and characters. But it doesn't have any "God tier" songs that I would put on my mp3 player so it's "just" a 9 out of 10.Graphics; Nothing extraordinary here, good dungeon prop variety and nice backgrounds makes the dungeons look good.But that's it, doesn't look bad or particularly good, it serves it's purpose.Art desing; Absolutely fantastic and very creative. The characters are very well designed, they are intersting, beautiful, creepy, terrifying. Things that look like a nightmare or a dream. (the game takes place in a nightmare) Levels are beautiful, and sometimes weird dream like. The menu is super cool.Controls; Oh my GOD the controls they seem bad, and they kinda are. But they aren't that bad once you figured out,  that you can actually climb over the ledges by pushing jump right next to them!!  You can also walljump which is completely useless and annoying. Blocking and dodging can get awkward too sometimes. Also might need X360ce for your controller to function.Replay value; Randomly generated dungeons with loot and secrets, every enemy has like a dozen moves not just 2 or 3 and you can play as enemies and bosses. With random encounters to keep things interesting. (some of them are pretty creative) It also has versus mode and co-op.

It can feel clunky if you're expecting a game where you can spam the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of your abilities. It's not one of those games. Time your blocks, get out of each other's way, and it shouldn't be an issue.If you like roguelikes and difficulty, this is for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												I reviewed this game for DieHard GameFAN. This is the short attention span summary of my review: Abyss Odyssey combines a myriad of genres to provide a unique experience that might not be to everyone’s taste. The platforming is wonky, the combat takes some adjusting, and the game is ruthless in its challenge. Enemies will react to your every move and pay you back in kind, plus the randomness of the dungeon layouts can work both for or against you and involve a lot of luck. Still, if you’re a fan of all of the genres represented here and can handle the steep difficulty, you’ll likely have a good time. Especially if you have a friend available to play along with you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												DO NOT buy this game, especially for $15.00.  If you get it free, I would still recommend you don't waste your time like I did.  I got it in a bundle and still regret losing an hour and a half of my time.I loaded up with a friend and jumped right into co-op play, here is the bad:- You start with two characters.  The girl is okay the guy is an obnoxious character to play as.- The game doesn't really tell you anything or explain any of the game mechanics to you.- I am not really into the story of games, but if I was, this game has nothing of interest to offer.- You go down into the Abyss and as you go down you get gold and buy things from the shops on each floor.  Problem is you don't gain gold at a comparable rate to the item price in shops.  Considering you don't get to keep the items when you die, the system that is in place is atrocious at best.- Speaking of this, in co-op you don't share loot which makes gold gain even harder.- During the course of play, they have some weapons laying around for free on the map.  Most of the time it says "not usable by the character you are playing".  So, not very helpful.- When you play co-op, you have to be on the same screen at all times, so if I drop down a level, I can't see my character.  The camera follows the host.- Jumping in the game is bad.- The combat is extremely clunky, even with a controller.  For the most part, it feels like your just mashing buttons when fighting.- The AI is ridiculous at times.  It's like they anticipate everything you are doing.  I'll throw fireballs at enemies who are fighting my partner and they somehow dodge behind my partner at the last second every time and the fireball hits him.  They feel like they are teleporting all over the screen sometimes.  Sometimes they'll just hold the block button for what seems like forever.- Speaking of enemies, they have way too much health for just being common enemies.  I don't want to play a game where every enemy feels like an HP sponge.  If your fighting more than 3 at once, good luck not getting stun locked for half your health or more.- When we loaded up, my friend wanted to turn off friendly fire.  The game said something about not being able to access all areas if you turn it off, so we left it on.  Talk about a terrible experience.  With the combination of having to be on the same small screen, the terrible jumping, the clunky controls and the enemy AI being obnoxious, good luck not hitting your co-op partner for at least a third of their health in each fight.Here is the good:- The graphics.- The music.tl;dr If all you like in a game is graphics and music, get this game when it's in a bundle for a $1.00.  If you want to have fun, there are 100's of cheaper games that are far less frustrating.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Great concept, but too many things holding it back. Abyss Odyssey has many things going for it: interesting story, nice graphics, an encapsulating theme. Unfortunately, it just doesn't feel right when you play it.Tutorial: the tutorial is very sparse. Sure it shows you what it wants you to do, but doesn't tell you the right inputs to do them, or the intricacies, like the difference between double jumping when facing a wall vs not facing the wall, or even wall slides. They don't teach you what number button quaffs what potion.Controls: The default controls are garbage, and should be reconfigured. Further, the tutorial doesn't really help you choose what suitable inputs should be. Ultimately, this leads to a lot of frustration for a player who want to just pick up and play. Combat: Combat feels a little clunky. It's slowed down in the interest of making combos, but it feels unresponsive at times. The AI doesn't have large enough tells. You would expect that weak enemies would have obvious precursors to their attacks, as would strong enemies' strong attacks, but many of the attack animations appear quickly and often seem uninterruptable. Lack of instruction is a problem here a well: There isn't any instruction as to how to combo. New players are left frustrated as the AI pile on multi hit attacks, while they are stuck with a basic 2 hit combo. Nothing tells players that the timing of the block matters in terms of breaking combos and counter-attacking. I disliked being constrained into artificial combat areas to fight particular non-boss enemies. It seemed unnecessary, particularly when they were already using a key system as a gateway. Also, being limited to fighting 1-3 enemies at a time was disappointing. I never felt overwhelmed by enemies, though at the beginning I did feel overpowered by them. Also, the enemies would often just stand still, waiting for your attacks! I felt as if I went to the bathroom and came back, the enemies would still be there waiting for me to make a move. Death Mechanic: Personally I liked the death mechanic of having a second chance, with a weaker character until you could find a revive spot. Environments: The levels are procedurally generated. Overall they felt luxurious, but sparse to me. I feel like there was a lot of wasted real estate, which could have been filled with smaller enemies. Unfortunately, the game seemed to want to focus on fighting one or two enemies at a time. The relatively linear exploration was somewhat disappointing to me as well. Inventory: You are allowed 1 weapon, 1 of each type of accessory, 1 soul transformation. If you want something else in a slot, you have to throw your current item away, and can't even sell it to a merchant. Very arcade video gamey, but not something I desire for a regular game. Would much rather have had a configurable inventory so I could switch swords. Plot: The fight seemed inconsequential after your first death. You die, you get reincarnated. Simple. What were the soldiers fighting for? Why didn't they just stay home and avoid the abyss, only guarding the exits? Were the monster's stealing children,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥women, setting fires? Nah, the soldiers just wanted to commit suicide by jumping into an abyss to fight said monsters. A lot of wasted potential here. Overall, this is a game with a lot of potential if you can get into it. However, it's lack of instruction, odd difficulty curve, slower combat system, and lack of drive will make it meh to most players.

												Extremely fun co-op gameplay and if you play with someone else on the default setting it can prove to be quite challenging. Friendly fire is a feature of the game, and being a side scroller beat-em-up means that combos are pivotal to clearing harder content. That being said, being juggled in your friend's combo while you can't do anything but watch and die means that you're not actually playing the game and since the encounter screen is quite limited this happens more often than you'd think.I'd say overall that it's a fun experience and definitely worth playing. There's full controller support so playing from your bed on a lazy day is definitely an option. For the price (especially during a steam sale), you get the most bang for your buck.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												What do you say about this game? I could tell you that the art style is gorgeous, evoking equal parts the saturated fantastical gloss of Trine and dreamworld fantasy with beautiful, clean Art Noveau.I could tell you that, mechanically, it's Smash Bros. meets a Roguelite.I could also tell you that there are technical flaws which harm the game in many ways, that the game is mostly balanced for playing alone and thus making the co-op modes nearly superfluous, not even counting the great technical flaws in the online co-op.In the end I will say that it is possible to get used to the technical flaws and that there is a great charm in playing what is essentially Smash Bros. with a stamina-based cancelling mechanic in a simple, Roguelite map with fantastic art and presentation. It starts out hard, but gets easier as you get used to the mechanics. If it still doesn't feel quite there, try disabling the V-sync in the options; for some reason, this helps the responsiveness even with a gamepad.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I love metroidvania games and I rarely write reviews, but I think this game has the potential to be a great game with only a few tweaks, so here I go...Although I really enjoyed several elements of the actual game (gorgeous visuals, music, level design, enemies and heroes characters and that low price is surreal for such an ambitious project), there are currently three BIG design ideas that I really hate:-Friendly Fire, I won't even argue much here as this is really obvious and already posted by several other reviewers - if you want to make co-op thoughtful in your game keep the "colision" part, but get rid of the damage! Just one additional note, friendly fire in fast paced platformers specially this one with a 2D fighting games combat system vibe simply don’t work well. It works much more towards increasing frustration, avoidance and restrict experimentation than adding excitement or tactical / strategic elements gameplay-wise.-Clunky controls, the controls schema is ok, but far from perfect. I'm using a X360 joystick and it would be great if the controls were as responsive as in some other recent 2D platformers like "Dust: An Elysian Tail", "Shank 2", "Valdis Story" etc or even real fighting games like "SFIV", "KoF 13" (slower) or "UMvC", BlazBlue" (faster) - specially the movement aspect: to block, parry, turn and recover.-No way to "save" between levels (there is a temporary way, an expensive and painful one, which means if you don't have the proper item, are far away in the Abyss and dies or don't have the time to finish the game, it's basically: gameover). FIX: just add automatic checkpoints in the current altars. For those of you that think this is a “casual gamer” request, let me elaborate: If you are not a bon vivant teenager and don’t have the spare time to play beginning to end every time you start the game (around 1h15) you will never enjoy this game as it already happened to me twice since launch when I got only about 20 minutes to play per session in my scarce free time. Checkpoints are needed to fix a design flaw that forces players to “play to the end at once or never play it”. PS: I hope you guys realize a checkpoint to save progress is a completely different thing than a free Healing Altar!I always try to respect and understand designer decisions (they are there for a reason), so for the first two points and to please everybody, simply adding a "Turn On/Off" option would solve it. Or even a difficult setting: Option1 (checkpoint to save + disable friendly fire) and Option2 (save costs items/gold + enable friendly fire).I believe this game has the potential to became one of the best 2D platformer games of all time, otherwise I promisse you I would never write a review this long, so hopefuly the devs will check the player's reviews and work on patches and enhancements. Until there, I found it hard to keep playing and/or recommend.EDIT:To end the silly “casual” versus “hardcore” arguing here, let me be very direct: AO is a really easy-to-beat game once you get the basics and have the mandatory free time (just learn to properly parry and level up your char to unlock the 3 cancels: done). If you believe my negative review points to help enhance the overall game experience is a simply “nerf the game’s difficult!” you are insanely mistaken.  If you want to play a hard game and not make a fool of yourself here, go play Dwarf Fortress (PC) or Battletoads (NES) – both great games btw.EDIT2:Kudos to developers! Only two days after release and patch 1.01 is already out fixing a major complain in the game (Toggle Friendly Fire On/Off is now possible), increasing some control responsiveness issues and more!EDIT3:After reinstalling the game and checking over the last updates I've changed my status review to a "recommended" game. Gameplay and other balances greatly improved in the last update! Kudos to developers!Best regards,

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												ACE Team are keen on creating memorable, talked-about games, and their latest creation, Abyss Odyssey, will do just that. In a blend of Metroidvania-esque levels, rogue-like gameplay and setup, and Chilean-inspired themes, settings, and design Abyss Odyssey will test your patience. But like the Souls franchise, you will keep coming back for more and more punishment. Why? Because you will never let a game get the better of you, and as a gamer, you have to see those credits roll. Okay, perhaps Abyss Odyssey isn’t that hardcore, but you get the idea. ACE Team has recaptured an idea that has worked for 20+ years with series like Mega Man, Castlevania, and Metroid. And while it’s not a complete overhaul of the genre, it’s a step in the right direction for the side-scrolling dungeon crawler genre.Everyone’s game will start the same: you’ll control Katrien, whose Rapier will allow you to make considerable progress through the procedurally generated dungeons on your way to tackle the Warlock in the Abyss. I say considerable due to the fact that it’s unlikely you’ll make it too far before Katrien is defeated and you must then, as a weak soldier, return to a nearby resurrection altar and return her to life, or start over from the beginning. Not all is lost if you die though, as your solider ‘spirit’ (so to speak) isn’t completely useless, but he’s a much weaker competitor than you yourself. Katrien (and your soldier companion) has a bevy of attacks and special moves to accompany you in your journey ranging from arching swipes, to fireballs, and sliding attacks. Utilized in conjunction with one another makes her a satisfying warrior, but the no-so-tight controls and platforming leads level exploration a lot to be desired.Platforming games have been around for decades, and they aren’t going anywhere, and when I get my hands on one, I’m personally spoiled by them. Having played every Mario game to death, Nintendo has perfected platforming; and with 2D Castlevania and Metroid games helping cement how graceful platformers can be, playing a game that’s a step back is really frustrating. Abyss Odyssey’s isn’t the worst of the genre, but it’s not up there with the best either. Most of the time, you can double jump then dash over crevices, but occasionally you come upon the dreaded ‘ledge’ wherein it’s 90% impossible to overcome unless you’re facing the right direction. Turning to get in the right direction is a bit of a delay, this making even the simplest of things, such as turning your character(s), rather cumbersome. Yes, this sounds almost elementary, but when you’re trying to hurriedly get somewhere and you’re halted in climbing due to such a minor inconvenience, it’s immensely frustrating. Again, it’s not ‘bad’, but it’s unsatisfying when it happens more often than it should.Another issue with Abyss Odyssey is its lack of real direction in terms of explaining what you can and cannot do. For example, when your mana meter builds, you’re able to unleash an attack that not only deals damage, but allows you to capture the soul of your foe. You’re then able to freely switch between the soul of your newly acquired demon, each with their own set of attacks and moves, to help in the journey. Unfortunately, none if this is really implied or explained. ACE Team has created a world I want to explore, but provides no understanding of the rules or regulations. As far as plot goes (another lacking feature as far as its delivery) comes in the form of pages of the Warlock’s journal that randomly drop from vanquished adversaries. The twenty page journal tells you everything about the Warlock’s beginning, middle, and end, but not much else aside from small bits about the creatures in the Abyss. I’m all for subtlety and minimalism, but at some point explanation and direction is needed, and Abyss Odyssey loses on that front.What’s found in Abyss Odyssey is a solid exploratory platformer with minor aggravations, but with rich design marred by poor direction and exposition. You will spend hours upon hours collecting enemies, hunting through the various dungeons, and defeating the famed Warlock; and then come back for more. With multiple playable characters, each with their own distinctive characteristics and attacks, there’s enough content to provide second and third playthroughs. And while we were unable to test this while playing pre-embargo, ACE Team promises a ton of continuous changes and additions to the game as more and more people complete the task of defeating the Warlock. Abyss Odyssey holds a world of fun in itself. In the end though, it’s just a shame that what’s here, although it isn’t genre-changing, isn’t enough to pull it from the depths of a dozen of other lookalikes. There’s a bevy of treasures to discover in the great below, however, so don’t pass up the chance to explore it. When Abyss Odyssey stares in to you, smirk and say ‘let’s go’!(Review via Front Towards Gamer: http://ftg.operationsupplydrop.org/2015/02/09/hyperdimension-neptunia-rebirth-1-review-pc/)

												I've played this game for a few hours during the free weekend and it's pretty addictive, mainly because of its rogue-like elements, leveling up your character and diving further and further into the abyss.Pros:+ I really like the art style. Characters are unique and pretty weird. Great atmosphere in every level; it feels a bit like Trine.+ You can morph into the enemies you've slain! That's really cool.+ The RPG elements are pretty well done, although I'm not too sure about the skill points. As in every good rogue-like dying really matters and resources are limited.Cons:- Abyss Odyssey feels like a mixture of Rogue Legacy and Super Smash Brothers, but the controls are clunkier than both of those games (and that's not really a good thing). - It's hard to time attacks, especially since most enemies instantly block. But maybe I'm just a noob at this game.- Unsure about the replay value. There are quite a few unlockable characters, but I doubt the game is entertaining enough to do multiple runs.I wouldn't pay the full price, but I recommend picking up this game on sale (currently 3 euros). I still want to try out local coop.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Abyss Odyssey is an awesome fighting game with some cool rogue-lite elements. There are lots of unlockable characters and every game is a random dungeon. You could say that the game gets repetetive, because it consists of smashing hordes of enemies on your way to the boss fight, but personally I love this game because it consists of smashing hordes of enemies on your way to the boss fight.As far as the fighting mechanics go, it's a lot like smash bros.  There are no easy combos.  At first a 4 hit combo seems impossible, then you will find a youtube video of an insane 10 hit combo.  This game is sort of an anti-button mashing game.  If you mash, you will be sent to bed without supper.  In my opinion, this makes the game terribly fun to play, as it's all about exploiting the range and timing of attacks.You can play as any enemy in the game, including the bosses, so there's lots of play time.  I've been playing for about 26 hours and I am still missing about 7 enemies or so.The art style speaks for itself, as everything is beautiful and weird.  this game is about to go on super monster sale soon, and it would behoove you to buy it.  It is an awesome fighting game, but you have to play by its rules.  Check out some of the combo exhibition videos on youtube.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												(I played on a controller, so I can't vouch for how the game plays with keyboard.)Abyss Odyssey has some pretty clever ideas and is a pretty fun 2D brawler after some adjustment. Most of the problems I have with it are related to the co-op. First, the netcode is just bad. When you're not the host be prepared for assets to not load in properly or at all, rubberbanding, and occassional gamebreaking desyncs (for instance my coop partner once just had a black screen and couldn't move, while on my screen they were standing in midair between platforms).  Second friendly fire being the default in co-op, just do yourselves a favor if you play this game co-op and don't turn friendly fire on. The menu argues the game is "balanced" for it, but the game is really plenty punishing without your partner stabbing you in the back, and sitting in your side of the arena waiting for an enemy to break off from your partner so you can safely attack them is pretty lame. Additionally, the enemies don't have friendly fire and can freely stack up and overwhelm you, and more of them spawn in the cooperative mode.There are also a lot of cheap shots in this game. You'll drop into a pit and a waiting enemy will attack you before you can even see what's happening, or you'll hit a trap. Enemies will spawn right on top of you immediately whipping out punishment. It's not terrible when you're prepared for it, but still bleh.As a single player game it's pretty well balanced and fun. I really enjoy the simple "smash bros" emulating controls, although the game does lack the polish and nuance of smash I still respect that direction. The art is pretty great, although attack animations are sometimes a bit wonky. Ultimately, if 2D Brawlers aren't your standard fare there are better ones to try first, but if it's a favored genre then Abyss Odyssey is certainly worth a look.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												I picked Abyss Odyssey up on a whim as something to do with the wife and considering that I've enjoyed the hell out of ACE's other titles I wasn't too worried about this one. So long as you go into it with the expectation of dying often you'll have a hell of a good time working your way through the depths and ultimately fighting the Warlock. The best modern examples I can use to describe this title is it's Dragon's Crown slammed together with Trine and topped off with your standard Rogue-lite affair (Binding of Isaac, Rogue Legacy, etc...). The mashup works surprisingly well with general RPG character progression (stats and skills) complimenting the randomized loot and progress resets.[PROS] Visually the game is fantastic and at times a little unsettling in a good kind of way. The audio is pretty well done, nothing incredible but it does its job and didn't irritate me after extended periods of play. The actual dungeon crawling is a blast and the monster transformation gimmick is pretty great once you figure it out. Local co-op is a huge bonus and the game is generally even more fun when sitting on the couch alongside someone else with controllers in hand. [CONS] The game doesn't do the best job introducing itself to players and it took me multiple hours to really get the hang of combat and progression. Fights can at times feel a little unfair depending on how quickly you pick up on the invincibility frames of your skills and the AI tendencies of your opponents. A few of the environmental hazards don't telegraph very well which can make certain sections a little frustrating, in particular the "Thwomp" like enemies you'll encounter further down the tower. I experienced a couple of bugs, some less impactful (wrong VO playing) and others more so (unable to move left/right). None of the bugs aside from the movement one really broke the game and even then I made it my mission to try and traverse the level using nothing but dodges (which I succeeded at).If you're like me and you love Rogue-likes and Metroidvanias I think you'll really enjoy Abyss Odyssey and its unique blend of the two. That being said, this game isn't for everyone and some of the problems I had with the game warrant a knock on the score.7.5/10Note: I did not try out the Versus game mode nor did I play co-op with friendly fire turned on. This review is based on some solo play but mostly couch co-op.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												This game is actually quite good. I'm impressed with how many techniques they were able to take from fighting games, and the execution of them inside a platformer Roguelike is doubly impressive. The game is set up similar to a roguelike dungeon crawl-- go in, fight your way to the bottom, fighting a few bosses along the way, and defeating a final boss. But what makes it so good is the depth of the mechanics, and how they work together-- You may choose from three basic characters, yet there are many more available. To get them, you have to defeat them with a super and then you can pick up their soul-- and thus, you are now playing as a fully featured character whenever you want to transform. While you can only carry one soul at a time, it gives a much deeper mechanic to the game: Should you opt for a monster early on to help you along, or save the super to get one you really want later? It takes quite some time to fill up the mana meter, so the choice is important, as it gives you a whole life bar to survive longer. Each enemy plays completely differently, but gives a great deal depth as a result.One thing that should be mentioned is that the game might feel somewhat slow and a bit clunky at first. I feel this is actually a good thing, though, as it leaves the player able to improve and attack much faster than is initially able, giving a real sense of progression in an intuitive way. This ties into progressing: If you're not good enough to defeat the enemies, you won't reach the end.Speaking of the enemies, they are NPC opponents, which inevitably means they're 'not perfect'. That is to say, they're sometimes too perfect and too good at reading what you're going to do. I'd love to see more work made to improve on enemy AI as the game's life progresses, but this is my only real gripe, and it's not even a big one. The enemies are certainly able to be defeated, it's more of a survival gauntlet than anything, but sometimes they adjust their behaviours a little too fast when you input something.All in all, an extremely enjoyable game, which I hope will have a fruitful life and a large community. The quality is astounding for the price of the game; puts many AAA games to shame.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												This game isn't perfect, but it's one I've really come to enjoy. I'd definitely recommend playing this with a controller. My main complaint (which seems to be *the* complaint in general) is that the controls are a bit awkward. The combat took a little getting used to, but I got there in the end. Using the practice arena or the area before you select your entrance for the abyss helped me out. For some reason jumping is also oddly difficult, and looking at other reviews I'm glad to know it's not just me.The replay value isn't the best (yet for some reason I personally find myself coming back to play more). Definitely give each character a shot though - I've found that I've enjoyed playing as Monk and Pincoya more than I've enjoyed playing as Katrien. Experiment with your special attacks and see what fits your personal style the best. It makes a massive difference.The art in this game is truly amazing. My love for Art Nouveau became helplessly solid after playing this game! The music isn't bad, but sometimes I'm just not in the mood for it and I turn it down and play whatever else I want instead. The game alt+tabs with no worries, but the pause menu doesn't seem to be a pause in the expected sense, but when it pauses you can still take damage when you're in the middle of a fight. There are clever and interesting references to various mythology and other games throughout the game, and I didn't pick them all up straight away. It was nice to realise them later.I paid full price for this game and I don't feel ripped off. However, I know not everyone else feels the same way. I recommend the game, though. Ultimately it's a fun and beautiful game that I fell and love with and I keep coming back to, despite some of its flaws.

												First things first, this game is beautifully crafted. It is certainly one of the most visually appealing games I have played. I am typically not a fan of this style of metroidvania inspired game. Primarily because I am simply not very good at them and they become frustrating rather than fun fairly quickly. With this game I find that the story and visual appeal continue to draw me in. Even though I am not very good at the game, I continue to come back to it because I am curious to see what will happen next and what new environments will be revealed as I slowly progress into the abyss. I highly recommend this game. For those who like me, are not very adept at platforming hack and slash games a patient approach is well rewarded. For fans of metroid and castlevania, you do not want to miss this game. It is a stunning and amazingly deep experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												So there are some really mixed reviews here. I'm not going to say vague things like the controls are "heavy", tell you what art style it is, or load my review up with quotes. No offense to anyone.This game is awesome. Let me express some things.-First, the combat system is actually very good. AI is well done and while exploits exist the oppostion isn't given crazy stupid powerful moves to compensate for lack of design. As well, if you think anything is overpowered guess what? You get to use a dream catcher and become one.-If you want to button mash use the ghost monk, it has very straightforward arcing attacks and the bouncing ball of flame can hit stuff you didn't even know it was going to hit. Not that you can't get skilled with the ghost monk. If you want to play quick and use reflexes play as katrien. If you want a mind puzzle that pays off use pincoya.-Use the surroundings to fight, it's one of the best things you can use to fight. If you have a guard helping try to flank your opponents.-Keep your enemies back by striking. You can hit one, dodge across the room, and hit another. Then jump dodge back to the first. One of the really cool things about this game is both you and the enemy get to hit on your way up from the floor and can dodge straight through some attacks. One great thing to do with a bit of practice is to use a ranged attack to get your opponent to dodge straight into your weapon. When they end their dodge you have a free shot for a follow up combo.- When you get to the fountain room you can get all the gold, take your time killing all the lame monsters for xp, and pick up a couple health potions, then exit the game and come back and do it again. Multiple times! Which is great to do if you don't like dying. But honestly, get ready to die. This game let's you keep everything but your gear. And rewards you after you die usually. You get new characters and all. Don't take it too personally, you literally only start back at the top and lose gear. Which you will regain from another waltz below.-Gear - Buy what you need. But everything has it's place. High damage output can be the difference between trying real hard to keep your health up and just walking through enemies. But I probably wouldn't buy high damage gear until I'm looking to get real low in the abyss. Accept that you'll die and have fun. One of the coolest things about this game is that you won't retain or have access to the same gear. You'll pick up a couple gear pieces most likely and buy a couple others. You might find some gear that you buy anytime you can find it. You might change your combat style because certain items are just too hard to get a hold of. You might end up like me forced to play something unusual and end up loving it.-If you are low on health, not a ton of awesome gear and an altar nearby... die. Let the guard hoof it back to the alter and reward you with full health. What a champ. And on that note. Dodge/attack is one of the best things a guard can do in combat.-Wear out your dreamcatcher first. After the monster you are turned into dies you come back as you. You can also change out of monster form to pick up health globes. And mana globes collected automatically go to your characters mana bar.-Use camp tokens in the earlier levels. Especially before the fountain room. It let's you stock up on things and gives you plenty chances to run into merchants that can sell you things for your big fight at the bottom.-Don't expect Nightmare mode to be beatable. It's supposed to be stupid hard. Laugh when you die. You're playing nightmare mode, you probably aren't that sane to begin with.If you do all these things you will likely enjoy the game much, much more... the game you probably spent like <$10 dollars on. It's not hard to live up to $10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Abyss Odyssey is procedurally generated, side scrolling Beat 'em up. The player is tasked with venturing deep into the procedurally generated abyss with the goal of killing a warlock. In order to accomplish their goal, the player must learn the secrets of the abyss through trial and error. failure is common.Throughout the abyss, the player will battle a multitude of dangerous creatures through melee combat. This combat feels sluggish and stiff initially. Later on however, it becomes much more enjoyable as the player masters the combat system and unlocks more moves. As a result Abyss Odyssey runs the risk of turning new players away before it gets interesting. Players who persevere are rewarded as they learn how best to combo moves and abilities together effectively, yet even in it's later stages, it lacks some of the polish found in other side scrolling Beat 'em ups. I found that using a controller helped a bit with some of the combat's issues, as the game was clearly designed with a gamepad in mind. Altogether the combat is decent, but not great. Little things like not being able to change directions in the middle of a combo and poor aerial combat drag the experience down. Where Abyss Odyssey's combat makes up for it's lack of polish is in variety. The number of playable characters is surprisingly impressive, and while many are not as developed as others, they still help change up the combat occasionally.I was also pleasantly surprised by Abyss Odyssey's procedurally generated level design. While nothing groundbreaking, the levels it generates feel well constructed and reasonably different. While they still lack the same tightly focused nature of many hand-made levels, they serve as a good backdrop for the game's combat, even mixing in a bit of light platforming to break things up. Throughout these levels Abyss Odyssey offers the player many opportunities to make risk reward based choices which leverage immediate reward against the risk of long term peril. While a nice system, I rarely found any situations where the risks outweighed the benefits, effectively undermining the tension these systems could have created if they were more effectively balanced.Abyss Odyssey's most notable feature is its art and music. The environments on display are beautiful to look at and manage to help disguise the procedural generation. Character designs are especially good. Each one is reasonably interesting to look at. As a result, I always enjoyed seeing what creature I would stumble upon next. Abyss Odyssey's soundtrack is also fairly good, and manages to capture the mood of the game just right. I especially liked the eerie guitar pieces, which add to the unique atmosphere.Despite it's numerous flaws, I still believe I can give Abyss Odyssey a cautious recommendation. Anyone interested in a procedurally generated Beat 'em up will likely be satisfied, so long as they can overlook some frustrating design elements.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												I reviewed this game for DieHard GameFAN. This is the short attention span summary of my review: Abyss Odyssey combines a myriad of genres to provide a unique experience that might not be to everyone’s taste. The platforming is wonky, the combat takes some adjusting, and the game is ruthless in its challenge. Enemies will react to your every move and pay you back in kind, plus the randomness of the dungeon layouts can work both for or against you and involve a lot of luck. Still, if you’re a fan of all of the genres represented here and can handle the steep difficulty, you’ll likely have a good time. Especially if you have a friend available to play along with you.

												I can't recomend this game to anyone. The visuals are extremely dark, the controls feel unresponsive and clunky, moving isn't natural (more often than not i found myself walking backwards and having to completely halt all movement flick the stick then start walking forward) and worst of all, the person who bought me the game got to try the tutorial, I didn't even get the chance to try it. The art of the game is painfully bland and dark as well and since you start out with only one character in the story it gets very confusing when two people use the same character as the color pallette is a very tiny shade darker to tell the players apart instead of simple color coded arrows.Combat is frustrating solo as you'll find youself repeatedly knocked down by enemies as they just chunk your hp but when you can manage a single combo on them it feels like you're hitting them with a pillow. I can't honestly recommend this game to anyone. It fails as a brawler, fails as a platformer and fails as a roguelike. The game feels as if it is still in alpha.  So unless you're wanting to play a bad game for some sort of joke or online review stay awy from it. I got it as a gift and I want to give them their money back.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												Abyss Odyssey is a beautiful game with a nice gameplay and combat mechanics. It focus on the Hero/Soldier duality, when the Hero dies then a Soldier comes to continue it's progress. You have a chance to revive the Hero at an Altar if you make it that far. The Soldiers are weaker but still capable on their own and provide an interesting gameplay ideia: you're forced to do with the Soldiers what you could not do with the Hero.The art style is incredible, all characters including enemies are very well design and the environments fit well within the game. The combat is varied and allows you to choose between 3 Heros + 3 Soldiers + about 20 different monsters you can summon once in a while. Each one has its own style and unique special abilities.The game is a bit difficult, to get to the final boss you have to pass through many levels with different difficulties and if both your Hero and Soldier dies you're back to square one. There are checkpoints along the way to save progress but these require tokens which are quite expensive. Any attempt to defeat the final boss is an expedition that requires preparation and nerves of steel.Pros:- Amazing art style- 3 heros to choose + a bunch of other playable characters- Good combat - Random generated levels improve replayability- Made by the Zeno-Clash boys, guaranteed seal of AwesomenessCons:- Controls are a bit slugish- Better to play with Xbox controller- Being bum-rushed to death happens from time to time- Random generated levels end up being repetitive- Difficulty
