It is a bit short, and after you reach a certain point it looses a bit of its replayability, but it hooks you in with a strange and flavorful atmosphere. Overall, it is definitely worth the buy during a sale. It isnt necessarily golden,but its worth your time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												DO NOT buy this game, especially for $15.00.  If you get it free, I would still recommend you don't waste your time like I did.  I got it in a bundle and still regret losing an hour and a half of my time.I loaded up with a friend and jumped right into co-op play, here is the bad:- You start with two characters.  The girl is okay the guy is an obnoxious character to play as.- The game doesn't really tell you anything or explain any of the game mechanics to you.- I am not really into the story of games, but if I was, this game has nothing of interest to offer.- You go down into the Abyss and as you go down you get gold and buy things from the shops on each floor.  Problem is you don't gain gold at a comparable rate to the item price in shops.  Considering you don't get to keep the items when you die, the system that is in place is atrocious at best.- Speaking of this, in co-op you don't share loot which makes gold gain even harder.- During the course of play, they have some weapons laying around for free on the map.  Most of the time it says "not usable by the character you are playing".  So, not very helpful.- When you play co-op, you have to be on the same screen at all times, so if I drop down a level, I can't see my character.  The camera follows the host.- Jumping in the game is bad.- The combat is extremely clunky, even with a controller.  For the most part, it feels like your just mashing buttons when fighting.- The AI is ridiculous at times.  It's like they anticipate everything you are doing.  I'll throw fireballs at enemies who are fighting my partner and they somehow dodge behind my partner at the last second every time and the fireball hits him.  They feel like they are teleporting all over the screen sometimes.  Sometimes they'll just hold the block button for what seems like forever.- Speaking of enemies, they have way too much health for just being common enemies.  I don't want to play a game where every enemy feels like an HP sponge.  If your fighting more than 3 at once, good luck not getting stun locked for half your health or more.- When we loaded up, my friend wanted to turn off friendly fire.  The game said something about not being able to access all areas if you turn it off, so we left it on.  Talk about a terrible experience.  With the combination of having to be on the same small screen, the terrible jumping, the clunky controls and the enemy AI being obnoxious, good luck not hitting your co-op partner for at least a third of their health in each fight.Here is the good:- The graphics.- The music.tl;dr If all you like in a game is graphics and music, get this game when it's in a bundle for a $1.00.  If you want to have fun, there are 100's of cheaper games that are far less frustrating.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Third review after patch 1.10My rating: 84/100I am glad to rewrite this review and finally give this game what it deserves. I do not know, what happened, but certainly, it all got better.Combat changed to challenging feature. System became innovative, creatures are skilled and force you to vary your attacks, so forget, you will beat a game with a single one combo. Some moves are illogical, but these are just simple details.Finally, save system works. You do not have to be afraid, that turning off the game will erase your progress. So, camp tokens are back in the game, it is worthy to buy one, because dying without them means you have to start from the beginning, which is the purpose of this feature.There are three locations to start, also with three characters to pick. Sabre wielded Katrien, using magic and fast attacks, more heavily equipped Ghost Monk, who takes the form of the souls caught within the Abyss, fighting mainly with double-handed sword. Last is Pincoya, fairy-like woman equipped with polearm. Each of the characters has a different approach to the game, another point, what assures that game will remain enjoyable and playable.Art is fantastic, chilean environment, their army from the nineteenth century, all depicted in Mucha's painting style.Soundtrack is also catchy, I may finally say, that this game is worthy of every cent spent. I am looking forward to another adventure searching for the route in the warlock's dream.You can find here some real and mythological beings, surely, changed as mighty mind twistes the world around. Just to mention Paganini, Verbum Dei and wise man, that gives wisdom for gold.Thank you, ACE team, for bringing this game to us and hearing us out. It was longer, than I desired, but in the end, I am satisfied. Recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Going to be pretty brief on this review, so it'll be in sections.Artwise: Abyss Odyssey is... well. Lovely to look at. I don't think anyone expected anything else. Though rather then the Fantasy-Punk vibe of Zeno Clash it is instead something of an Art Nouveau fever dream. Its distinctly late 19th century Chilean, and honestly that makes it feel almost as unique as ZenoClash. Simply because of the lack of well, games with that vibe.The Fighting: It is not bad. It is also not that great. It reminds me heavily of the old Squeenix brawlers like The Bouncer or Ergheiz (especially the adventure mode) The primary point that needs to be understood is you absolutely must cancel animations in a careful pattern to actually make combos.  There are moves with a certain number of hits, but chaining together moves and quickly dispatching enemies, or preventing yourself from being torn apart requires a different skillset then most fighting games do. It's kind of like Orb Walking in a MOBA. I enjoy it greatly, but I think it should be called a 'side-scrolling combo-brawler' over a 'fighting game'. The only flaw I see is it takes some getting used to to figure out how not to get stuck in animations, and some things feel unresponsive. (Turning isn't as bad as people say it is, but it COULD use some work. I imagine it'll be tweaked in the future.  I also have a feelong allot of the extremely negative reviews are from earlier builds as right now, it's quick.)The story: Small, compact, folklore rich and not particularly invasive. Its not some mesmerising story with a gripping narrative, but its a functional fairy-tale that conveys a rich and enthralling world. It takes multiple trips into the abyss to actually tell its tale.The Monster-Capture-thing: Gonna be honest, I am sad. SAD I SAY. I reeeaaaaally am a sucker for cute monsters, and would love to just be able to choose them at the start of the game after catching them. However, despite people's reviews, they're more then a damage sponge (an alternate pool of hitpoints, really) While they can serve that purpose, they've got interesting movesets with specific advantages. Some of these can be used to cheaply deal with certain enemies. (The mimic can absolutely trash a few for instance) While others are more all around useful and versatile or even allow better terrain navigation. (Pudutaur is incredibly mobile and has fantastic range on her melee)Finally. Pudu-Taur. Seriously. Pudutaur. That enough should sell the game. Don't know what a pudu is? Look it up. Pudutaur.Pudutaur.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												As the title says, this game is quite the odyssey. It's easy to get lost into this Chilean fantasy. The artwork is drop dead gorgeous, The game plays as a platformer beat 'em up with RPG and roguelike elements. The combat is pretty satisfying, featuring parries, dodge rolls, direction-based attacks and special abilities as well, though the controls aren't as tight as I would want them to be and enemies essentially reading your inputs in order to punish every mistake you make can get quite frustrating. The level design is randomly generated, and pickups are randomly placed as well which leads to a lot of replay value.Despite it's shortcomings, Abyss Odyssey is a very enjoyable game and definitely worth your time and money.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												First things first, this game is beautifully crafted. It is certainly one of the most visually appealing games I have played. I am typically not a fan of this style of metroidvania inspired game. Primarily because I am simply not very good at them and they become frustrating rather than fun fairly quickly. With this game I find that the story and visual appeal continue to draw me in. Even though I am not very good at the game, I continue to come back to it because I am curious to see what will happen next and what new environments will be revealed as I slowly progress into the abyss. I highly recommend this game. For those who like me, are not very adept at platforming hack and slash games a patient approach is well rewarded. For fans of metroid and castlevania, you do not want to miss this game. It is a stunning and amazingly deep experience.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Yeah, this hit all the right buttons for me.Abyss Odyssey is a beat 'em up game with fighting game mechanics and loot grabbing - it has platform levels that change every playthrough, loaded with traps and secret rooms.Bad- controls are wonky. it's set up to attack left and you have to face right again and then press right to go in that direction. Some of the characters are limited because they are too big for an area or, in the case of the first soldier, cannot climb walls at certain heights. It's pretty flawed in these specific control problems. Most people cannot overlook this (thus the mixed Steam reviews) and I don't blame them.Good - but what shines in this game is the art, animation and design. The whole drips with polish and satisfying visuals in the art style of Art Nouveau masters like Mucha. The characters are strange and interesting with amazing movesets and fantastic animations - some of the pick-up enemies are more fun to play than the three main characters! The story is facinating Chilean myth with a bizarre twist that makes the mood eerie and one of a kind.Basically, if the controls were patched, this would be one of my favorite games, no doubt about it.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												I got Abyss as part of a humble bundle, but I got the bundle, in part, because I wanted a good game to play with my steam controller.  I am not very familiar with dungeon, rogue-like or brawler type games.  But I really like this game.  I haven’t quite beaten it but i’ve faced off with the final boss 3 times now.  ProsGood visual style, excellent art.  Another game proving that video games are a legitimate media-art form.  Controls seem fluid, easy to use.Interesting setting and story.The game is really unique and interestingThe three paths system of difficulty seems like a great system.ConsI don’t like that I lose my items when I die.  I know this is “rogue-like” but I wish there was a little more character progression.I wish the texture res was higher, OR that there was better texture filtering.  My characters have jaggies around them.Your incentivised to play as your backup garud character when you enter the final chamber as your main character will then be resurrected with full health.  There seem to be 3 different weapon classes and as such I cannot pick up weapons that are hard-won 2/3rds of the time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Nice blend of roguelike, platformer and beatemup genres. You are able to capture defeated enemies' souls and play as those creatures yourself switching between them and your main char on the go giving you immense tactical possibilities.  Yes, ALL of the enemies in the game have a full arsenal of standard, forward, high, low, jump etc attacks in both fast+weak and slow+strong variations. Dashes, grabs, rolls, blinks, magic projectiles, spinning AOE and vomiting poison make combat both varied and challenging. Unfortunately, all this gorgeousness comes at a price: instead of Metroidvania-styled gameplay Abyss Odyssey is way too much linear and kinda lacks other content. The whole game is just a succession of randomly-generated beutiful 'biome' arenas that consist of a single vertically-oriented long corridor with a few dead end branches that have loot in them. More often than not when you reach a predetermined point in the arena enemies just spawn offscreen and you are locked in a small 1-2 screen sized battleground until you defeat them or die trying sorta JRPG-style. Apart from that and a handful of NPCs that train you or sell you stuff there is nothing to interact with. Don't get me wrong, Streets of Rage+Megaman roguelike is a welcome thing, but i'd prefer a +5-10$ in a price tag and a bit more content to deepen gameplay a bit (DLC maybe?).As for drawbacks, kb+mouse controls were a bit clunky, but now devs seem to have fixed everything and I was able to beat the game fwo times out of three tries while I haven't been able to beat it even once before due to unresponsive controls so I got rekt in harder levels because of slow character response. Also devs got a tiny bit lazy and out of a few dozens of enemy types (ALL PLAYABLE!) a couple are just a reskinned or posessed versions of your own characters, doubling as minibosses every now and then, but there is a good variation of unique bosses too though so it's not that bad.All in all a nice game i'd recommend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												TLDR: Very short game (4hrs or less) with great astetics and premise but an end result that is not worth the price. Consider only  if it is on sale by 75% or more, you like linear dungeon crawlers and  ONLY  if you own a controller. Otherwise stay clear.Full review:First of all, no, this is not a non recommendation due to the controls as it seems to be the case for a lot of other Steam reviews for this game. I actually found the controls to be pretty good and easy to learn ON A CONTROLLER (do NOT play this game otherwise, it IS a nightmare to play using the keyboard).Gameplay is pretty interesting, mainly thanks to the movement and attack controls which make even the very first enemies you encounter a decent challenge. However it can also get a bit too repetitive when most of the enemies follow a very similar pattern and you can even do the same tactics to defeat them, even to the point where you can stun-lock them on endless grab-throw moves ("final boss" included).I really love the asthetics and theme of this game, the artwork and spine-chill lovely music really gave me the good old Castlevania vibes. Even the voice acting feels like top quality with its few dialogues (that guitar playing skelleton chilling = GG). The big negative point why I cant really recommend this game, is the fact it is very, VERY short. Barely 4 hours in, as a below average skill player and I already cleared the 3 entrances to the Abyss, unlocked the 3 playable characters and gathered pretty much all of the "journal pages". There is nothing left to do other than probably try get a couple achievements if I was ever interested on those.Another letdown is that while the game presents you with what could be a very complex and interesting developing story about the origin of the abyss and of the characters you play as, it ends up being mostly told on the previously mentioned journal texts you can find after killing enemies and from what little dialogue there is each time you reach the Warlock. You kill the final boss and what do you get?  a pretty background and a "Yay, you did it! But guess what? the Warlock is still alive! Play again!" kind of message.  Nothing more, regardless of how many times you do it.If you see this game super cheap (75% discount or so), you feel like playing a very linear dungeon crawler and you own a controller, I'd say go for it and give it a try not expecting much, I had fun playing it but its flaws really outweight the good stuff unfortunately and at this price, there are a lot of far better games out there.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Why hello there friend. Say, do you enjoy ATLUS games? Do you enjoy roguelikes? Well how about fighting games, surely you enjoy those. If the answer to any or all of these questions was a resounding yes then I have some great news for you! Abyss Odyssey is a game which manages to combine all of those things into one complete package - and then some!This game has beautiful visuals, strong atmosphere and easy to get into yet hard to master gameplay. The combat has more in common with a fighting game than a simple side scrolling action RPG, there are several quick button combos and cancels that can be performed across each character giving all of the heroes (of which there are 3) a unique feel. The core game mechanic is that of the roguelike, you will enter into the randomly generated abyss and proceed up ways and down ways and sideways and the like, each section offering new peril and new reward. If you enjoy games that have a dark yet almost serene atmosphere about them I would say this is definitely one to pick up, the game does a great job with its varying environment types within the abyss and the subtle musical accompaniments contribute to that package.Like most roguelikes you can expect there to be a bit of a difficulty curve, items and levels will always be lost on death but your wealth will remain with you to make your next decent a bit easier. If you are on the fence about this one but you enjoy any of the things I mentioned above I would say go ahead and pick it up, it's worth it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												(I played on a controller, so I can't vouch for how the game plays with keyboard.)Abyss Odyssey has some pretty clever ideas and is a pretty fun 2D brawler after some adjustment. Most of the problems I have with it are related to the co-op. First, the netcode is just bad. When you're not the host be prepared for assets to not load in properly or at all, rubberbanding, and occassional gamebreaking desyncs (for instance my coop partner once just had a black screen and couldn't move, while on my screen they were standing in midair between platforms).  Second friendly fire being the default in co-op, just do yourselves a favor if you play this game co-op and don't turn friendly fire on. The menu argues the game is "balanced" for it, but the game is really plenty punishing without your partner stabbing you in the back, and sitting in your side of the arena waiting for an enemy to break off from your partner so you can safely attack them is pretty lame. Additionally, the enemies don't have friendly fire and can freely stack up and overwhelm you, and more of them spawn in the cooperative mode.There are also a lot of cheap shots in this game. You'll drop into a pit and a waiting enemy will attack you before you can even see what's happening, or you'll hit a trap. Enemies will spawn right on top of you immediately whipping out punishment. It's not terrible when you're prepared for it, but still bleh.As a single player game it's pretty well balanced and fun. I really enjoy the simple "smash bros" emulating controls, although the game does lack the polish and nuance of smash I still respect that direction. The art is pretty great, although attack animations are sometimes a bit wonky. Ultimately, if 2D Brawlers aren't your standard fare there are better ones to try first, but if it's a favored genre then Abyss Odyssey is certainly worth a look.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Would like to preface this by saying I could see this being enjoyable for people into this kind of game but it just wasn't for me.Pros:I really enjoy the art style of this game.Atmosphere is nice as well the rooms can change pretty drastically.Interesting set up with dungeon rooms varying in difficulty, it lets you take a quick way down through alot of hard rooms or plan a longer way that may hit easy/medium rooms more often.The soul collection for an extra life and skill set is a neat mechanic.Cons:Repeatative in every way, aside from collecting souls there are only 3 characters and the soldiers you become when you die. The game is basically running the same yet different (Randomly rearranged) dungeon over and over.The leveling is pointless really, it's simply a gate on which souls you can capture.Really doesn't feel like there's much of an end goal to it, since winning just lets you start again and dying starts you again. I haven't managed to win yet but I'd assume you'd get to keep your weapons in that case. Losing your weapons on death makes sense for some difficulty but also ruins any feeling of progression you achieved.Ranged attacks are almost useless since the AI is godly at dodging them, they can be used to bait them in but rarely for damage, in my noob opinion.Ultimately I bought the game for it's style which I still enjoy but the game just isn't enjoyable enough for me to play that much. But if you're curious I'd suggest watching some gameplay videos to see how it looks to you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												What do you say about this game? I could tell you that the art style is gorgeous, evoking equal parts the saturated fantastical gloss of Trine and dreamworld fantasy with beautiful, clean Art Noveau.I could tell you that, mechanically, it's Smash Bros. meets a Roguelite.I could also tell you that there are technical flaws which harm the game in many ways, that the game is mostly balanced for playing alone and thus making the co-op modes nearly superfluous, not even counting the great technical flaws in the online co-op.In the end I will say that it is possible to get used to the technical flaws and that there is a great charm in playing what is essentially Smash Bros. with a stamina-based cancelling mechanic in a simple, Roguelite map with fantastic art and presentation. It starts out hard, but gets easier as you get used to the mechanics. If it still doesn't feel quite there, try disabling the V-sync in the options; for some reason, this helps the responsiveness even with a gamepad.

												An interesting idea, but the controls are painfully awkward, and combat is incredibly stiff.  You move incredibly slowly and your attacks don't combo very well, which throws any sense of flow out the window.  The controls are especially annoying when it comes to platforming, because the game can be very picky about getting on platforms and climbing ledges, so getting around is quite annoying, even out of combat.The graphics are quite nice at least.  They remind me of Path of Exile, with a similar gritty style, and it works quite well.  It would take a lot more than that to save the game though.Overall, there were a few good ideas buried under technical incompetence.

												Smash Bros meets dungeon roguelike.Tho not exactly.  Abyss Odyssey brings a very dark but vague experience.  There's not much in the way of story or background, and it's a pretty straightforward dungeon crawl.The game is also incredibly challenging.  If you are frustrated easily or can't stand games you can't beat, this is not for you.  Multiplayer coop introduces friendly fire (which can be turned off at a consequence to progression), meaning you have to fight smart with your teammates instead of just hack and slash every damn thing like it was Diablo 3.I'd recommend this game to anyone who has a good solid team of friends who aren't discouraged easily.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												Jogo bem legal, gostei bastante. Apesar de parecer um jogo de plataforma comum, ele oferece mais coisas do que aparenta. Os combates são um pouco chatos pra pegar a manha mas depois que vc aprende, o jogo fica bem divertido. Vc deve aprender os padrões de golpe do inimigo pra então planejar o seu ataque e acredito que esse seja o principal motivo de tanta gente não ter curtido muito o jogo. Não adianta vc ficar apertando freneticamente o botão do controle esperando atingir o inimigo o máximo de vezes possível. Se vc jogar assim, não vai conseguir chegar muito longe e vai acabar se frustrando. O combate é o que na minha opinião tornou esse jogo bem divertido. Não chega a ser aquela coisa apelona do dark souls hehe, mas bem de leve lembra um pouco, pelo fato de vc ter que calcular os movimentos dos inimigos e quando vc deve o atacar.As fases são geradas aleatoriamente, por isso cada vez que vc morre, volta ao começo. O objetivo do jogo é passar pelas diversas cavernas até chegar no chefão final. Quando o personagem morre, vc mantém o progresso dele e também o dinheiro coletado. Nessa estrutura das cavernas, existem 3 níveis, fácil, médio e difícil. O padrão de dificuldade também é aleatório, vc pode tanto ir por uma trilha só com cavernas de dificuldade fácil ou logo de cara ter que passar por uma com a dificuldade difícil.No começo é meio difícil pq como as fases e dificuldades são geradas aleatoriamente, vc já de cara pode ter que enfrentar 2 fases da maior dificuldade, e nisso vc vai penar pra passar por que seu personagem está ainda fraco. Mas ao longo do jogo e à medida que o personagem subir de nível e ganha novas habilidades, juntamente com o fato de que vc provavelmente irá controlar melhor o personagem por ir pegando a manha dos combates, o jogo fica bem mais tranquilo. Quando eu cheguei mais ou menos no nível 10, já consegui chegar na penúltima caverna antes do chefão final sem morrer nenhuma vez.A trilha sonora do jogo é bem legal, casou bem com a atmosfera das fases. Os gráficos são ok, nada muito extraordinário mas também longe de serem ruins. O ponto forte é pra paisagem das fases, que são bem desenhadas e o design dos inimigos, que é bem psicodélico. Eles até me lembraram os inimigos do jogo Zeno Clash, que foi feito por essa mesma produtora.O único ponto fraco do jogo é o controle, que poderia ser mais preciso. As vezes os comandos não saem e isso frustra um pouco, mas nada que chegue a tirar a diversão do jogo. No mais, eu recomendaria esse jogo pra quem gosta desse estilo em plataforma e também goste de jogos mais difíceis e desafiadores. Se vc procura um jogo desse estilo porém que seja mais casual e mais simples, eu recomendaria procurar outras opções. Acho que esse jogo é meio 8 ou 80, ou vc vai gostar muito ou de cara já vai odiar e deixar ele de lado.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Just got this game...And because of the mixed reviews, I'd thought I would leave this review in favor of the developers.At first, it looked a "little dark" but the art was amazing and what really turned me on to it was it's "Inception-like" concept of going deeper and deeper into someone's dreams.So--the plot begins when a giant hole in the ground opens up to reveal a deep cave termed "the abyss," someplace in Chile. This "abyss" releases these imaginary monsters that the soldiers (or the people for that matter) can't handle or hope to fight against.This is where you, the player, comes in, as the hero Katrien, an unexplainably attractive swordswoman with a strong will, long red-hair (maybe that explains it) and a mission to stop this horrifying but random event from continuing.The intriguing part of this plot is the fact that every being ascending from the abyss, the main character Katrien, as well as the abyss itself are all just products of the dreams, thoughts, and memories of a supposed "sleeping warlock" who lies underground, at the bottom of the abyss. And this is where the plot itself runs hand-in-hand with the rogue-like gameplay of this title.Because everything is IMAGINERY -- When your character dies (and the soldier that tries to revive your character), you just spawn back to the beginning to try again and again--retaining only your level and gold with each playthrough. On top of that, things that don't exist pop up and beat you in ways that don't quite make sense sometimes (either that or it can be credited to a lack of skill either way--it sucks dying).Because everything is a DREAM -- The dungeons are procedurally generated--which translates to the abyss appearing differently each time you venture into it. Furthermore, it's not just the scenery that changes, but the pathways that you take, as well as the difficulty of each section of the dungeon changes as well--just like a dream would. It's also good to note that the variations of the abyss don't always appear to be inside of a cave--this makes for some pretty interesting visuals during each trek.The combat system is NOT a "clone" of Super Smash Bros. (despite some negatively making a comparison of the two games) but being a Super Smash Bros. fan myself--I could definitely see how the developers were influenced and inspired by the title's combat. The characters controls are similar which makes for simple but strategic battles. One thing that you'll notice when first starting is that the controls seem extremely stiff--but after playing and getting the hang of it--you'll soon realize that they're not REALLY stiff but that they are actually extremely tight.Now, there are a couple of things I don't want to leave without mentioning--One--is the fact that Katrien isn't the only playable character in the game. There are 2 other main characters that are unlockable in the game--The Ghost Monk (which you will probably unlock first) and Pincoya. On top of that, when your character's mana bar fills up, you're able to (sort of) "capture" pretty much anything you face in the abyss so that you can become whatever it is you want (insert pause). And of course, I can't forget to mention the weak and clunky soldier guy that you have to control after dying with your main character--it sucks but really it's just best to think of him as a "place-holder to a second chance shot at going further." On top of that--I want to mention the artstyle of the game. This game is beautiful. It's like turning a museum into your playground and because of this artstyle--I can't help but say that this game is like staring at your most horrid nightmares and falling in love with them all at the same time. And no matter what, every time you head into the abyss for another playthrough, there's always this sense of adventure that takes hold because the game is so well designed in the way of making you, as the player, feel as if you really don't know what to expect once you're in there.This game is unique and honestly, my playthrough(s) of this game has really brought me back to the time I first played the Vanillaware title "Muramasa" on the Wii and that's a REALLY good thing.I wanna see more games like this.- Last BeNeVoLeNcE

												Abyss Odyssey has a unique and fascinating aesthetic that pulls from art nouveau, symphonic metal, and Chilean folk tales.  I absolutely love it! 												Pros:-Beautiful art-Awesome soundtrack-Great concept-Interesting storyCons:-Awkward combat and movement mechanics (very still movement, blocking, dodging, and countering is often pointless)-Restrictive offensive and defensive capabilities-Some important items are lost on first death (You die, but have a chance to revive your character before losing the run)-90% of equipment you find wont be useable (and even if it is, the effect boosting rings are useless 70% of the time)-Mostly about grinding experience until you have enough HP to do anything-Monster difficulty scaling is very steep-The best way to combat enemies is to abuse their AI, spam ranged attack while hiding behind a soldier, or memorize the perfect position to hit enemies into the air against a wall so you can juggle them until they die

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												Quite Fun But Very Challenging!Just tried this game out on a whim and it is actually quite fun.  Surprisingly it is a 2d random map sidescroller that plays quite a bit like super smash brothers!  As a fighting game fan I actually notice quite a few things you normally don't need to worry about in games EXCEPT for a fighting game (Armor, cancelling, frames etc.)  I have logged 9 hours so far but am still really liking it.  Something kind of trippy about venturing into the encarnation of a mad warlock's dreams and the whole game feels surreal.  I would recommend it but be patient.  The game is quite difficult and takes some studying to be effective.  Even once you get it you will still have some hard times decending into the depths.

The thing about ACE team (the creators of the game), is that they make games with HUGEEEEE potential, yet they fall when it comes to gameplay and basic things. theoretically, their are games are AMAZING, but when it comes to the actual gameplay, you realize that they had a great plan that has gone to waste (same with Zeno Clash sadly).Abyss Odyssey is an awesome challenging game, that falls down when it comes to the combat and momvment. the combat is really repetive and boring, as you spam pretty much everything, while trying to doge and avoid pretty much everything.On the other hand, the art style, the music and the voice acting (yeah, thats right, unlike the voice acting in Zeno Clash - the voice acting in Abyss Odyssey is actually pretty good!) are all awesome, it's just that the combat is really frustrating.Well, the bottom line is - a great game, with huge potential (just as Zeno Clash has huge potential), but somthing went horribly worng along the way. meh, such a shame.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												This is a dungeon crawler grinder and I haven't been so frustrated with a game in a long time. The way the game is, you really need to weigh the importance of your options and decisions. When you die, the game punishes you: you drop all of your items (including your weapon), and have to start over in the dungeon (the abyss), unless you use a camp token, which will allow you to respawn at a marked camp. However, camp tokens are expensive (I think the cheapest is 4,000 or so gold), and all of your items and your weapon will be gone. Which means any gold you spent on those items is wasted. Luckily, you get to keep the gold you earn, so I recommend grinding to level up your character to at least level 35 and to have a good 40,000-50,000 gold.At times, the platforming is atrocious, which I think is more so the fault of the controls. The way the keyboard controls are is annoying. The controls aren't really explained, if not cryptic, I accidentally skipped the prologue and have no way to go back to it unless I restart the entire game (I think). Sometimes the controls get...confused? I'm not sure how to describe it, but I'll try to jump down, but instead jump up. Sometimes double jumping is a chore.I didn't figure out how to Soul Capture (which is holding down your normal attack button and your special attack button at the same time i.e. left and right mouse buttons) until I was level 40 and about 10 hours into the game.Battles can get repetitive and annoying. I think it would be nice to see the level of your enemies, as opposed to having to guess and then get killed and have to start all over. ESPECIALLY when it comes to Soul Capture-you cannot capture the soul of an enemy unless you are of an equal or greater level.The inventory and menus can be annoying to navigate as well.I think what really kept me going was the art. The character models, particularly the enemies, are very nice and modelled very well. The backgrounds and environments were also very well-put together artistically and the art direction in this game is solid. The consistency in the style and tone is quite nice, and the blend of Chilean culture and art nuveau was an interesting but overall good combination.I did have a good laugh though-the mummy enemy design is directly based off a Harry Clarke illustration for the Edgar Allan Poe story, "Fall of the House of Usher". The demon Paganini is also based off a real person, Niccolo Paganini, and they were pretty accurate with his physical depiction (MUTTON CHOPS) although I feel the evil bad demon man cliche they have for him makes him an obnoxious character.I think the developers were more focused on the art and story, and the gameplay suffers from it. It's not unplayable, persay, but there are a lot of small annoying issues that test your patience as a player. Overall, I think it's a relatively solid game that just needs more work on the gameplay mechanics, less vagueness on controls and maybe a bit more gameplay variety as well. I think the difficulty also really alientates and limits the games' audience.If you can get past the flaws and issues, it's a nice game. Not amazing, but also not bad.

content:
Posted: January 5
												I'll admit, it takes a long time to get a good grasp on the controls, timing, and even gameplay mechanics, but this game is really fun and worth it. Currently one of my favorite games.If you ever got good at Street Fighter or Mortal Kombat, you'll get the hang of this. There are more moves and characters to unlock and you can slightly customize the special moves with higher levels. There are moves you might not realize you can do until you do them on accident.I have a couple of tips: 1) If the enemy blocks a lot, walk up and throw them. It's the B button on a 360 controller. Just get really vicious and relentless. You can even air throw with the monk so that's my favorite. Besides that it looks bad♥♥♥♥♥ Even when you die, you continue and keep what you've unlocked. You have to start back a ways but you can chose different paths to different areas. And fighting your way back is even more fun the next time - especially because you'll have gotten better at the game and have more allies you can control and fight with. Other parts of the world become more easily accessible. It starts getting really fun so why give up? It's very challenging but not frustrating. The computer AI is no chump, and that's a good thing. Sometimes they thrash you and sometimes you thrash them. But you learn and they don't. :p

												This game is a very weird game, and I like it.A very nice game with some RPG elements, I really had fun in my 9 hours of playing this game all though the content of this game wouldn't take you more than 3 hours to see everything (1 or 2 hours for hardcore gamers).This game is creative, something fresh, it has a lot of cool concepts and ideas, for instance, you can almost play as any enemy in this game each with their own unique special moves and character, also it goes for less but harder enemies’ style, and the art style is awesome, the music is nice too.The game has a lot of flaws as well to be honest, for example there is really a considerable lack of content here, and the length of this game is very unsatisfying, the end is unsatisfying and it's too zoomed out, it would look better if the camera was closer.Anyway, the game is worth full price in my opinion, all though it's preferable if you can get some kind of discount on it, I recommend this game, and I give it a solid 7 out of 10 in my book.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Its definitely worth a try. The combat system leaves a bit to be desired... you can have enemies on either side of you and if you want to switch direction to fight the other enemy you have to stop fighting and turn around which does not happen instantly. For me this is annoying because it removed the feel of fluidity from the fight. Played it with a friend which was fun   for sure... but we both noticed a huge lack of opportunities to regain any health after combat from slain enemies or smashing containers. Also we did not like how you have to PAY for your checkpoints with coins, and not just a few coins either. I've never in my life seen a game that required payment for a much needed checkpoint. Another big annoyance was loosing all your weapons and powerups that you payed a bunch of coins for when you die. After a couple instances of that we just stopped buying anything except for health vials.All b-itching aside this game is very interesting and colorful. The music is very groovy. And there really is a lot of potential here. But that combat system (in my opinion) could use some tweaking. If nothing else being able to change directions while fighting would be a serious improvement.
